item.title: [PAXLOGGING-1] Appenders as OSGi services.
item.description:
It would be cool if one could define Appenders as OSGi services, which are detected by Pax Logging upon service registration and make themselves available.

Log4J has centralized configuration, and uses class names to identify the appenders, and the configuration of the appender in the same config file. This is not really cool, and having the configuration for each appender managed by the Config Admin Service for the appender service would IMHO be a better way.

Appenders can be added to each Logger directly, as a an instance (not a classname) which solves the Import-Packages issue in OSGi.

Another concern is that many appenders would use formatters defined in the standard Log4J system, so the Pax Logging bundle should probably expose these log4j packages.
item.summary: Appenders as OSGi services.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: This issue also brings up if another configuration format should be done, prior to 1.0 release. And perhaps even reconsider using Log4J "as-is" the backend.

I will probably create a "Pax Logging NG", which will fork Log4J, remove the complicated Configuration system, clean up all the internal crap that has evolved over long period of time and make it an integral part of Pax Logging.

When doing so, Appenders, Filters, Layouts and Object Renderers will be broken into separate bundles, most of them being ManagedServices and more suitable for OSGi use.

Work on this will start in laboratory/users/niclas/logging soon, and no commitment to ever being completed. Work will progress in bursts.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-7] Compliance with 101.6.4
item.description: LogService must deliver LogEvents to the Event Admin service, according to the clause 101.6.4 in the R4 Compendium Spec.
item.summary: Compliance with 101.6.4

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: The clarification is going to come from Kriens & Co, via the osgi-dev mailing list.

The OSGi spec is badly written. The LogService is not responsible for the delivery of the Event to the Event Admin service, but the Event Admin service is responsible to subscribe for log events from the LogReader Service and redistribute them. Backing out the change.
Incorrect interpretation of the Spec. bug-467 in OSGi Alliance is taking care of the bad wording.

The CPEG has clarified and now says that the LogService indeed is responsible for sending the event if the Event Admin service is available.

The Log Service is free to drop events if/when the Event Admin is not available, but could buffer if it wants to.
I have put back the changes made in April. Still need to go through some serious testing.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-10] pax logging outputs wrong class and line number
item.description:
This is my favorite log4j appender:
log4j.appender.stdout.layout=org.apache.log4j.PatternLayout
log4j.appender.stdout.layout.ConversionPattern=%d %p [%t][%C:%L] - %m%n

I like to see the class and line number that does the logging ([%C:%L]), but with pax you get this:
...[org.ops4j.pax.logging.internal.PaxLoggerImpl:78]...

So I don't get the originating logger class and lines in the output.

slf4j is used within the code, which works fine with when using slf4j/log4j without pax-logging, so it seems to me this should be feasable for pax logging as well..
item.summary: pax logging outputs wrong class and line number

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
I'm not an expert on log4j, but maybe you should check out the slf4j log4j implementation:

class: org.slf4j.impl.Log4jLoggerAdapter

it contains the following snippets:
(...)
/**

  • Following the pattern discussed in pages 162 through 168 of
  • "The complete log4j manual".
    */
    final static String FQCN = Log4jLoggerAdapter.class.getName();

(...)
public void debug(String msg, Throwable t)

{ logger.log(FQCN, Level.DEBUG, msg, t); }

I did some poking around, and log4j just checks the stacktrace of the current call as to show which class it has to output.
The FQCN argument above then contains the class that gets called with the log statement. I checked this and hacked the following line in PaxLoggerImpl

public void debug( String message, Throwable t )

{ m_delegate.log("org.ops4j.pax.logging.internal2.TrackingLogger", Level.DEBUG, message, t); // m_delegate.debug( message, t ); }

Now log statements appear like:
2007-07-24 14:37:27,197 DEBUG [Framework Event Dispatcher][org.apache.commons.logging.internal.JclLogger:89] - 2 beans defined in

2007-07-24 14:38:45,694 DEBUG [btpool0-1][org.ops4j.pax.logging.slf4j.Slf4jLogger:68] - getting list size

So I guess the call stack is something like
myclass->facade(jcl/slf4j)>TrackingLogger>PaxLoggerImpl

So if you somehow can determine which classname to use when logging m_delegate.log, you should be able to fix this.

I hope this isn't too much work...
I think this issue has been fixed, but due to lack of time, I have not been able to test it.
I've tested it, but allas, still not the correct line numbers.. For my slf4j all the line numbers are 68, so I guess that's still slf4j talking.

Ah! I understand. There is an additional legacy layer in between, which also need to be accounted for.

Bear with me, I'll get this right.

I have now made an incompatible change in PaxLoggingManager (shouldn't be a problem), so that the FQCN of the legacy API is passed and used in the PaxLoggerImpl.

However, I suspect that there will be a problem with Log4J API, since that will appear twice on the stack trace, once for the Legacy API in the Pax Logging API itself (the right one), but also inside the Pax Logging Service where Log4J is used as the back end.

Perhaps it is time to break up Log4J into pieces and evolve independently... Need to look closer at that option.
target 1.0 release?
to my knowledge, this issue was already fixed in 0.9.7
Marking as resolved in 0.9.7

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-15] OSGi TCK test failure: LogEntry instances have null bundle fields
item.description: Most of the LogEntry events generated by Pax-Logging have null bundle fields, because the calling bundle is not provided in the LogService API. To fill in the bundle field we need to implement the ServiceFactory interface and supply a customized instance for each bundle that basically delegates to the underlying Pax-Logging service instance.
item.summary: OSGi TCK test failure: LogEntry instances have null bundle fields

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Fixed - used a local class to maintain the interface list (using proxy was overkill)
With this change, Pax-Logging 0.9.9-SNAPSHOT now passes the R4 OSGi TCK!

I don't understand this fix nor the problem. PaxLoggingService returns a PaxLogger with the Bundle in it, and should be possible to always pass Bundle info along.

Also, the spec allows the Bundle in the LogEvent to be null, if not associated... Let's discuss this when we meet next time. Meanwhile I will re-open the issue, so I don't forget it.

OK, it's really quite simple... the LogService API calls don't contain a bundle parameter, for example:

m_logger.log(LogService.LOG_INFO, "This is a test");

So without a service factory there is no way to know which bundle is calling any of the log methods.
The OSGi TCK checks that the LogService implementation can find the calling bundle for various
logging calls, so without this fix we fail much of the TCK.

If you look at other LogService implementations, they all use the same service factory approach.

Ok, so the spec requires the LogEntry to contain the Bundle, even when there is no ServiceReference passed into the log() method??

I don't have the Spec with me right now. Could you add to this issue the paragraph where this is mentioned? If it is not mentioned, then there is a bug in the spec and should be reported to OSGi Alliance...

Then close this issue again.

Section 101.8.2.1, page 12 of the compendium spec states that for the LogEntry object:

public Bundle getBundle( )
Returns The bundle that created this LogEntry object; null if no bundle is associated with this LogEntry object.

though if you were being picky then you could say this doesn't stop you from returning null in all cases.

Also sections 101.8.5.5 to 101.8.5.8, page 15 of the compendium does mention explicitly when the Throwable and ServiceReference fields of the LogEntry will be null for different combinations of log(...) but never says that the Bundle field will be null for any of these combinations.

Finally note that while some log(...) methods pass in a ServiceReference, this should not be used to fill in the Bundle field, because it may not relate to the calling bundle, as the service was most likely registered by another bundle - so even in these cases the calling bundle (as provided by the service factory) should be used.
This issue has been fixed
Fixed and available in the latest release.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-17] NoSuchMethodError: org.apache.log4j.Logger.log(Ljava/lang/String;Lorg/apache/log4j/Priority;Ljava/lang/Object;Ljava/lang/Throwable;)V
item.description:
Error while creating instance of com.mchange.v2.c3p0.ComboPooledDataSource:

Instantiation of bean failed;
Caused by: java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: org.apache.log4j.Logger.log(Ljava/lang/String;Lorg/apache/log4j/Priority;Ljava/lang/Object;Ljava/lang/Throwable;)V
at com.mchange.v2.log.log4j.Log4jMLog$Log4jMLogger.log(Log4jMLog.java:159)
at com.mchange.v2.log.log4j.Log4jMLog$Log4jMLogger.log(Log4jMLog.java:162)
at com.mchange.v2.log.MLog.<clinit>(MLog.java:80)
at com.mchange.v2.naming.JavaBeanReferenceMaker.<clinit>(JavaBeanReferenceMaker.java:39)
at com.mchange.v2.c3p0.impl.PoolBackedDataSourceBase.<clinit>(PoolBackedDataSourceBase.java:203)
at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0(Native Method)

Log4jMLog:159:
private void log(Level lvl, Object msg, Throwable t)

{ logger.log( FQCN, lvl, msg, t ); }

where FQCN is String:
final static String FQCN = Log4jMLogger.class.getName();

So it is called:
Category.log(String, Level, Object, Throwable) which is not present in Logger from pax-logging-api!!!

This metod is still present in log4j 1.2.15:

/**

This is the most generic printing method. It is intended to be
invoked by <b>wrapper</b> classes.

@param callerFQCN The wrapper class' fully qualified class name.
@param level The level of the logging request.
@param message The message of the logging request.
@param t The throwable of the logging request, may be null. */
public
void log(String callerFQCN, Priority level, Object message, Throwable t)

So I think pax-logging must support it to be compatible with log4j.
item.summary: NoSuchMethodError: org.apache.log4j.Logger.log(Ljava/lang/String;Lorg/apache/log4j/Priority;Ljava/lang/Object;Ljava/lang/Throwable;)V

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
I disagree with the generic statement "So I think pax-logging must support it to be compatible with log4j."
Log4j allows you to navigate all the inner guts, and not separating what the true API really is, from SPI and just internal workings. We will NOT support all possibilities in this area, and you might find apps that won't work, and they probably won't work when Log4j upgrades/downgrades/sidegrades.

Now, that said; For this particular case...

Without in-depth check, it looks like this is usage of MDCs in Log4j. Both MDCs and NDCs were considered by myself beyond the level of support wanted. Agreeably my own personal opinion and not at all debated.

We have a couple of choices;

1. Ignore this (you not happy)
2. Implement a hack and ignore NDC and MDC aspects.
3. Create a Context system for Pax Logging.

I am actually been assigned to upgrade the Log Service spec for the OSGi Alliance, and one of the items I have brought up myself is the need for context-aware separation of logging, so I can differentiate between "Audit Trail" and "Debug Tracing" for instance.

No, I think this is not usage of MDCs nor NDCs.

It's 3rd overloaded "log" method, the others are:

void log(Priority priority, Object message)
void log(Priority priority, Object message, Throwable t)

While my missing method has one more parameter - String callerFQCN:
void log(String callerFQCN, Priority level, Object message, Throwable t)

It seems to be SPI interface, because all of them have comment:
/**
This generic form is intended to be used by wrappers.
*/
And actually in c3p0 they are use in c3p0 log4j wrapper - class com.mchange.v2.log.log4j.Log4jMLog.

So it is against implementing it in pax-logging, because as I understand pax-logging is API compatible not SPI compatible.

But... there is a precedence: method void log(Priority priority, Object message) is already implemented in pax-logging!
So why not implement other log method??? For example:

public void log(String callerFQCN, Priority level, Object msg, Throwable t)
{
// ignore callerFQCN parameter

if( priority == Level.FATAL )

{ this.fatal( msg , t ); }

if( priority == Level.ERROR )

{ this.error( msg , t ); }

if( priority == Level.WARN )

{ this.warn( msg , t ); }

if( priority == Level.INFO )

{ this.info( msg , t ); }

if( priority == Level.DEBUG )

{ this.debug( msg , t ); }

if( priority == Level.ALL )

{ this.trace( msg , t ); }

}

I think callerFQCN may be ignored. In c3p0 it is hardcoded string with Log4jMLogger class name. In log4j Category FQCN = Category.class.getName().

Of course I can manage without it - I can create own MLogger for c3p0, using supported by pax-logging API.

But I think it would be worse for other pax-logging users.

Ok, then sorry for my noise about MDC/NDC.

I am Ok to implement the method(s). However, the follow-up from someone will probably be that the callerFQCN shouldn't be ignored. Let me check this, and do so before the RC1 is released.

I have added the two missing methods

public void log( String callerFQCN, Priority level, Object message, Throwable t );
public void log( Priority priority, Object message, Throwable t );

to the org.apache.log4j.Logger class.

item.environment: Felix 1.0.0, Windows XP Pro, Intel Core2 Duo T7500, 2.20 GHz
item.summary: Frequent lock-ups when starting felix

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Our startup configuration file. We tried using runlevels to split up bundles to help, but the problem remains.

After a first quick look, the "real reason" is that Felix is clever and finds the implementation class of the LogService, and calls that directly for its own internal logging needs.

Right now, I have no good idea on how Pax Logging could assist in avoiding this. Will discuss with the Felix folks about it.
Workaround for the time being; If you set the Log Level to 3 instead of 4, this particular deadlock should not occur. That is done in your submitted Felix configuration file.

Karl Pauls at Felix is asking if this happens in Felix 1.0.3 as well, since some locking issues has been fixed there. This version is being released "right now", and is available at http://people.apache.org/~pauls/felix-1.0.3.html. OPS4J will upgrade Pax Runner to use it as soon as it is official, in case you are using that.

Meanwhile, I will try to investigate if these locks remains.

The provided stack trace is also about a case when the Class was not found. Trying to follow the actual code for the "normal case", and a similar lock happens slightly before the above one, albeit extremely short in time

synchronized (m_factory)
{
// If the module is already resolved, then we can just return.
if (isResolved(rootModule))

{ return; }

and the isResolved() makes a HashMap lookup. So, I think it can happen but much more unlikely.
Actually, it has nothing to do with "likely", since this is the second lock and will not be acquired.
The workaround you suggested of changing Log Level to 3 instead of 4 has been successful. I have not seen a single lockup since I did that . Thank you.
Incidentally, why does the log level change make a difference? Does something start using logging sooner or later to prevent the lockup?

Couple of steps

1) the Felix Framework is always looking for a Log Service, and once found will use that to do its framework level logging.

2) there is a log.debug() in a synchronized block, which is held during resolve() of wires.

3) The Log4J instance that is backing Pax Logging, locks the Root logger upon
a) Configuration.
b) Log Output

So, the Config Admin thread will first lock the Root Logger, then call classloading, which hangs on the ModuleFactory lock.
The StartLevel thread will first lock the ModuleFactory and inside there call the log.debug(), which will hang on the RootLogger lock.

By setting log level = 3, i.e. INFO, the log.debug() inside the sync'ed block in the R4SearchPolicyCore never reaches Log4J.

Proposed fix;

If we just buffer the configuration in the update() method, and call the configure() during a log call instead, it should solve this particular problem. That is a fairly low impact workaround, which solves this particular problem.

Alternate;
The Log Service backend could have its own thread, for all calls into the Log4J backend. This guarantees only a single lock in the call, hence deadlock free.

According Karl Pauls at Felix project, this has been resolved in Felix 1.0.4 and later.

Since I am keen on scrapping log4j totally in the backend, I don't think it is worth time investing fixing a decoupled log thread... So I mark this "Won't Fix.".

Reopen if someone is not satisfied.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-21] Malformed log messages with slf4j
item.description:
Hi,

Log messages are not correctly formatted when the log functions of an slf4j logger is called with an Object array.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-24] Internal stack of log entries
item.description:
Pax Logger keeps an internal stack of log entries = every logged message. This is done in order to fulfill the specs of Log Reader Service (101.4 compendium 4.0.1) getLog that returns an enumeration of the most recent log entries. As right now the size of this stack is unbounded meaning that it will keep any logged messages as long as the service is alive. As it can be a large number of messages in a running system the stack of can use a large chunk of memory after a while.
My fist suggestion is to limit the size of log entries to a configurable number of entries with a default of 50, FIFO. If someone needs a larger size they should configure it. This is also allowed by Log Reader Service specs.

Question is: how to support configuration?

  • via system properties: easy to use but not reconfigurable
  • via configuration admin: harder to setup and will interfere with the log4j configuration itself as the configuration property should be in the same configuration file.
    I suggest using configuration admin but with a different pid then the one used to configure the logging itself.

Another fact regarding specs is about what log level of messages should be kept into the entries stack. Specs suggest that only above DEBUG level. I suggest a configuration option with a default of INFO.

A more complex solution which I would consider is to have a log entry storage plug-able with a default in memory implementation that respects the above mentioned settings.
Then someone can implement different types of storages as for example persisting all messages on file system of database. Message persistence can be done also now via using log listeners but that will not work for getting the messages out of persistence store using the log reader service.
item.summary: Internal stack of log entries

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: The pluggable store is interesting. Mind you the very simple "query" interface in the LogReaderService, i.e. Enumeration getLog(), which in the case of a lot of data becomes useless, unless the newest entries are first. If the spec allows for that, then it would be neat. Otherwise, question is if we should introduce an extended LogReaderService interface with slightly better query capability.

Specs of Log Reader Service does say that the returned enumeration should be ordered in a way that last log entries are first. Does pax Logging do that? I do not know.
The specs does not allow any filtering on the getLog() method so I would say that a new spec is required. I can imagine that an system admin suing a console would like to filter the messages on info as log level, message contents, bundle location, bundle symbolic name, bundle version, exception type, exception message,...
We could do a simple approach like saving a dictionary of this properties/values via the persister and having a new getLog(Filter). Only disadvantage is that the retrieving data form the store then cannot be optimized as you have to get them all and apply the filter.

Anyhow I see another interesting problem here: Log Entry has getBundle() that will not longer be valid after is persisted. The in memory one can keep this info but is also dangerous as you will have references to the bundle preventing GC if they are hard references. Actually this problem is also in Pax Logger right now.

I don't have the code in front of me, so I can't recall the ordering. If the spec says, newest first, then I think we go with that only initially. If the Enumeration only do bulk retrieval of a dozen of two entries at the time, then I think we leave the rest for a tool (for the time being).

Other filtering can wait.

Holding references to Bundles --> Bad. Store the log entry in a Weak reference before putting it into the List/Vector should take care of that.

Persisted bundle references --> If we are clever, the Bundle-SymbolicName + Bundle-Version is persisted and potentially recreated upon retrieval. If the bundle is not available --> Not sure... null?

I'm thinking we should first fix the issue with a fix size buffer.
I have one ready to avoid recoding it:
http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/servicemix/smx4/kernel/trunk/gshell/gshell-log/src/main/java/org/apache/servicemix/gshell/log/LruList.java

Then, i guess a pluggable store would be nice, but later.
Imho, this is quite a critical issue for all pax-logging users.

o Fixed the Buffer clean up.

  • MaxEntries are initially 100, and can be configured via ConfigAdmin and the key of "pax.logging.entries.size".

o Fixed that the "latest LogEntry is returned first in the getLog() method.

o Fixed that WeakReference is used to hold on to ServiceReference and Bundle in the LogEntryImpl

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-26] deadlock when pax logging sends an event to EventAdmin
item.description:
I have two threads that often deadlock.

  • thread 1 logs the "unget" of my service, this holds a lock from the Felix registry, it's waiting for a linked list in EventAdminTracker
  • thread 2 (felix event dispatch thread) logs a framework event, holds the linked list in EventAdminTracker and tries to obtain the felix registry lock in order to find the Event Admin service.

In my humble opinion, this is caused by pax logging (EventAdminTracker), not adhering to the rule that an OSGi service should not hold locks when calling the framework.
Of course, one can debate whether Felix should hold a lock when calling ServiceFactory.ungetService(), but still, pax logging should not hold a lock when posting an event.

I agree with your conclusion, and I have no defense why the code has ended up the way it is. I must have had brain hemmorage that day... Will fix asap.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-27] IndexOutOfBoundsException in EventAdminTracker
item.description:
Occasionally, we get the following exception:

java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException: Index: 0, Size: 0
at java.util.LinkedList.entry(LinkedList.java:365)
at java.util.LinkedList.remove(LinkedList.java:357)
at org.ops4j.pax.logging.EventAdminTracker.deliver(EventAdminTracker.java:94)
at org.ops4j.pax.logging.EventAdminTracker.postEvent(EventAdminTracker.java:56)

The fix is trivial, i think: in the EventAdminTracker.deliver, a (synchronized!) check on the queue size is missing:

while( m_queue.size() > 0 )
{
Event event;
synchronized( m_queue )

{ event = (Event) m_queue.remove( 0 ); }

}
item.summary: IndexOutOfBoundsException in EventAdminTracker

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Feel free to commit yourself...
ok

So, i fixed the exception by adding an if statement within the synchronized. Although this fixes the bug (i.e. the IndexOutOfBoundsException), this does not guarantee that all events are processed, because the test in the while condition is not synchronized and the member is not volatile. Hence, an update on an other thread might not be seen...
To solve this, it would be better to rewrite the while loop, i guess; something like:
do {
sync'd( m_queue )

{ if (m_queue.size() > 0) event = ... }

if (event != null)
....
}
while (event != null)

Btw. the m_service EventAdmin member also suffers from not being volatile, while being accessed by multiple threads without proper synchronization.

Due to this and other deadlock issues, I wonder if we for 1.2 should just introduce a FIFO on the incoming log requests which are dispatched to a thread owned by Pax Logging itself.

That would make the synchronization needed in Pax Logging extremely well contained and easily understood, as well as solving this and the deadlock with Felix internals, and we can guarantee that we don't hold on to any locks in the thread calling out to Event Admin, while triggering classloading and so forth.
For what it's worth, the deadlock issue with Felix internals should be fixed as of Felix 1.0.4.
This has been fixed by PeterD himself in commit 11686. Will be part of 1.2 release, or sooner.

The previous comment/log was done using Spring 2.5.2 and Spring-DM 1.0.2.

This points me to the implementation of PAXLOGGING-24 Closed . This can explain also why is intermittent: the buffer of log entries is cleaned up when the size exceeds a limit, and that moment depends on the log messages and the moment that they are issued. As when starting up there is an random order (not guaranteed) it can be that on different runs you get different order or logging hence different places the error is thrown.
I'm looking now into the issue.

I cannot pinpoint the problem. In my view it should be related to the fact that the LinkedList used as a buffer it is not thread safe it looks like in some situations it just crashes, randomly.
I can use a synchronized list but this will only add overhead to logging so not sure what to do. For the moment I will go for the a synchronized list so to have a fast solution to your problem and maybe that later on we drop the consistency and speed it up.

I'd agree with SynchronizedList. My app is naturally multi-threaded and I am doing this with a Core2 processor so I guess it complicates the problem.

How about Synchronized Deque/Queue ? Rather than cleaning up buffer you can do partial purging based on the length of queue.

Regarding performance, I'd prioritize logger performance over getLog() / LogReader performance.

Of typical use case, everybody uses logging but not everybody wants to read contents of logging. So it's (LogReader) something that's used probably < 10% of typical use case.

Resolved (maybe as I do not know for sure that this was the problem) by synchronizing access to log entries buffer. This, may have an impact on performance but for now we better have a slower implementation then one that does not work.
I will create an "improvement" issue to address this possible performance problem.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-30] Replace synchronized access to log entries buffer
item.description: PAXLOGGING-29 Closed solution forced an synchronized access to log entries buffer. As the common use of logging is to log not to read the entries via a log reader we better "sacrifice" consistency of the buffer in favor of better performance by implementing a solution that is not synchronized.
item.summary: Replace synchronized access to log entries buffer

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
The problem is not so much of "reading" vs "adding" to a buffer, but the fact that many threads can add to the buffer simultaneously.
Since we can't rely on Java5 memory model semantics of "volatile", I can't figure out a better way and synchronize is inevitable. Suggestions are welcome.

Sending logging/service/src/main/java/org/ops4j/pax/logging/internal/LogReaderServiceImpl.java
Transmitting file data .
Committed revision 13755.

I've fixed some possible threading issues in the above commit.

I'm not sure how we could possibly remove the synchronized block on m_entries though.
I'm not aware of any concurrent bounded list, and even the ConcurrentLinkedQueue from
JDK 1.5 has a problem for our use: the size computing requires full traversal of the list so
it would be very costly.
I guess a faster way may be to use a rolling buffer to minimize the cost of inserting into the
list and avoid the instantiation of a node in the LinkedList.
The problem is not around reading vs writing but as I noted about "multiple threads write", and synchronization is (I think) unavoidable.

item.description:
Spring Security 2.0.2.A requires log4j version 1.2.15. Therefore it is not interoperable with pax logging.

Our first hack was just modifying the exported version in the manifest of the api bundle, which did not work since there are some new classes in log4j.

comments.comment:
I think the description of the issue is incorrect. Spring Security uses Jakarta Commons Logging in both the java import statements as well as the OSGi Import-Package statements.

So, you have a deployment scenario which you need to explain in greater detail.

However, I notice that there is for some bizarre reason no Export-Package of Jakarta Commons Logging package in Pax Logging 1.1.1.

Investigating this right now...

Interestingly enough... BND version 0.0.227 was used to generate the Pax Logging API 1.1.1 and it did the wrong thing. Regenerating the Pax Logging 1.1.1 from the captured sources right now, using BND version 0.0.255 will generate a correct manifest.

Okay, I was a bit unprecise. The bundle causing dependencies on log4j version 1.2.15 is spring-security-cas-client, version 2.0.2. We used ivy to retrieve all necessary bundles from the spring bundle repository.

Following the dependencies of this bundle we go along the following path:
-> org.springframework.security.cas (2.0.2)
-> com.springsource.org.jasig.cas.client (3.1.1)
-> com.springsource.org.opensaml (1.1.0)
->this requires log4j version 1.2.15
-> com.springsource.org.apache.xml.security
->this requires log4j version 1.2.15.
Both opensaml and apache.xml.security explicitly import version [1.2.15;2.0.0] of log4j in their manifest files.
Can you quickly test Spring Security 2.0.3, since they seem to have changed the dependency graph? And I would like to see we are covering this as well.
Spring Security 2.0.3 depends on jasic 3.1.3, which is not yet (publicly) available as an OSGi bundle. So unfortunately a quick and reliable test is not possible.

Well, I found it...

Funny enough JA-Sig CAS depends on OpenSAML 1.1 which uses Log4J (and quite intricately) whereas OpenSAML 2.0+ uses SLF4J...

And OpenSAML uses Category and NDC... don't like it... The 1.2.15 is actually incorrect. OpenSAML 1.1 depends on Log4J 1.2.5, and I think the 1.2.15 is a lazy thing from SpringSource...

I will look at this and see what I think.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-34] Configuration of Log4j Delegate Within PaxLoggingServiceImpl Varies During Startup
item.description:
While the PaxLoggingServiceImpl is in the process of starting, and before it has received configuration information from the ConfigAdmin, the log4j delegate can have differing behaviour due to its configuration. There are 2 main issues related to this:
1. The log4j configuration set during configureDefaults() always has logging set to ALL, and the PaxLoggingServiceImpl always returns DEBUG as its log level, so the user has no way to set a stricter logging level for the pre-configured logging service.
2. If a bundle makes a call against the PaxLoggingService before it has received a configuration event, the delegate logger created uses whatever log4j configuration the delegate finds using standard log4j setup, which again leads to varying logging behavior during startup.
item.summary: Configuration of Log4j Delegate Within PaxLoggingServiceImpl Varies During Startup

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-42] Implement org.apache.log4j.Category.isEnabledFor(Level)
item.description:
This is a request for pax-logging-api to support the isEnabledFor(Level) method on org.apache.log4j.Category.

Tomcat requires this method if using Log4j. The version of Tomcat provided by the SpringSource Enterprise Bundle Repository (specifically, the org.apache.juli.extras bundle) imports org.apache.log4j in this manner: version="[1.2.15, 1.3.0)" (See https://www.springsource.com/repository/app/bundle/version/detail?name=com.springsource.org.apache.juli.extras&version=6.0.18)

While it is an optional dependency, if the SpringSource bundlized Tomcat and pax-logging-api bundle are in the same container, Tomcat will not start, due to the missing isEnabledFor method.

– Michael Pilquist

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-43] Incomplete SLF4J Marker Support
item.description:
The SLF4J support for markers ist not working in PAX Logging API. The problem seems to be org.slf4j.impl.StaticMarkerBinder.getMarkerFactory() which simply returns null, although the comment says:

"Currently this method always returns an instance of

{@link BasicMarkerFactory}

."

I think this is the same code as in SLF4J, but there this dummy implementation is never used, because it is replaced by some real implementation. Since this is not the case in PAX Logging, the dummy implementation should be fixed to work.

Simply returning "new BasicMarkerFactory()" would fix this issue.

We found this bug when using Apache Tapestry (Version >= 5.0.15) together with PAX Logging.

Thanks in advance
Richard Schurig

Added a system property named "org.ops4j.pax.logging.skipJUL" which if set to true will disable the handler for Java Util Logging in Pax Logging.
Is there already a plan when a new release containing this change will be available?

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-50] Specify Log4j Logging Directives on the Command Line
item.description:
It would be nice to be able to specify log4j logging directives on the command line. For example, doing something like:

-Dpax.log4j.logger.org.springframework=WARN

The PaxLoggerServiceImpl ( http://www.ops4j.org/projects/pax/logging/xref/org/ops4j/pax/logging/internal/PaxLoggingServiceImpl.html ), when it goes to configure its default properties could then include all of these command-line specified properties. This would be useful because during debug sessions in Eclipse it'd be nice to quickly specify some directives via different run configurations.

Thanks

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-51] org.ops4j.pax.logging.DefaultServiceLog.level should be read via framework properties
item.description: Currently the default logging level can be specified via setting system property org.ops4j.pax.logging.DefaultServiceLog.level. This means that is read by using System.getProperty. But as we are talking about an OSGi environment in my view Pax Logging should use the BundleContext.getProperty for getting the property. This will allow setting the property via the framework property and system property as osgi frameworks must delegate to system properties in case that the property is not set in the framework itself.

item.description: If we use the LogReaderService all framework events (like "BundleEvent STOPPED") duplicated. But in the log-file which was generated by pax-logging are all framework events only once. Other log entries which we get from the LogReaderService are only once, too.

comments.comment:
To clarify;

For all LogEvents there are one entry in the LogReaderService, EXCEPT for framework events, which in turn show up once in Log4J output but twice in the LogReaderService??

We use the pax-logging-api to write a log file. In the log file are all events correct. But in the GUI of our application all framework events (like "BundleEvent STOPPED") are duplicated. Our application receives the log events from the LogReaderService, which is implemented by the pax-logging-service. If i debug the application I can see that the application receive the framework events twice from the LogReaderService.

Do you use an Event Admin Service as well??

I recall noting a inconsistency of how framework events should be handled in respect with the Event Admin service (unclear who was responsible for what), and if the Event Admin being used made the other interpretation (that it should forward framework events to Log Service), you would end up seeing this. This is just a hunch...
We don't use the Event Admin Service.
Fixed in commit 16428.
Released under 1.5.0

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
This has been a known issue from the start, as it is very expensive to try to locate the Bundle from where the call to the API class happens.

I will look into this again, to see if I can find a not so expensive solution. Suggestions are welcome...

The main issue is that the only way I know on how to obtain the caller is via the stack trace in Throwable. For 1.4, this has to be done with;

Throwable t = new Throwable();
t.fillInStackTrace();
StackTraceElement[] stack = t.getStackTrace();

But the StackTraceElement only contains the Class name, and not the class itself.

So, unless someone else can come up with a way to find the java.lang.Class of the caller, I won't implement the alternative; i.e. try to figure out which Bundle that the class may belong to, since not only is it needed to figure out the class space resolution of OSGi, but also the caller may be an internal class and potentially there is no public exposure to where the class comes from.

There are two alternatives that can work for "native bundles" (i.e. code that is OSGi aware);

a. Add a Pax Logging specific method to LogFactory, getLog( String category, Bundle bundle ), OR

b. Make Pax Logging an embedded system instead, i.e. the API must be placed into the client bundle, and initialized from that bundle's activator. (It is likely that this already works...)

Otherwise, I am out of ideas on how to tackle this.
Re-open the issue if you have some good ideas on how to solve it.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-58] Commons Logging LogFactory implementation is not a drop in replacement for commons-logging:LogFactory/LogFactoryImpl
item.description:
PAX Logging does not work with Axis 1.4 because Axis cannot find a LogFactory implementation. I have included the Exception below.

I believe this is because commons-logging-1.1.1 has a LogFactory implementation org.apache.commons.logging.impl.LogFactoryImpl with a public no args constructor and the LogFactory class in PAX logging does not (it is a private no args constructor).

This prevents commons-discovery from finding and instantiating a class that is "compatible" with LogFactory.class . I am in the process of testing this fix by making the constructor public.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Ok after changing the LogFactory constructor to have a public constructor I could get Axis 1.4 to work by adding the following System property:

-Dorg.apache.commons.logging.LogFactory=org.apache.commons.logging.LogFactory

commons-discovery lookups are still broken. I am investigating this now.

Uhhhh.... I suspect that you are using something incorrectly.
Pax Logging includes the commons-logging API, and you must ensure that this API is not present in any bundle, otherwise it might not work.

So, instead of messing with Pax Logging, I would like to get to the bottom of the actual problem, which seems to be inside commons-discovery. Can you find out exactly which version of commons-discovery that are being used?
Disregard that comment, as you already provided the link.

Ok, let's go again; IMNSHO, Apache Axis is at fault here, it make presumptions about the implementation that are just plain silly.

For instance;
public static Log getLog(String name)

{ return org.apache.commons.logging.LogFactory.getLog(name); }

uses the static class method, which is the 'default' way to obtain a Log instance, yet it doesn't use the equally public and static getFactory() method on the LogFactory abstract parent class, which would work with Pax Logging.

The fault is at Axis, which assumes too much about commons-logging implementation details, yet fail to use the simplest thing that works (LogFactory.getFactory()).

The current implementation of PaxLogging's LogFactory, might work with a public no-arg constructor, since all fields are static (I need to investigate why that is the case, because that is normally not how I would do it), but I strongly suggest an alternate solution.

Also, your remark; Public no-arguments constructor required by the lookup mechanism.

taken from the LogFactoryImpl is not relevant. I can agree that the people who created commons-logging weren't the best API designers or realized that they were in API/Spec territory, but they were. The result is one of the worst pieces of crap that has ever been made at Apache, and has been detrimental to sooooo many people in soooo many environments that I don't know if one should laugh or cry. If you want a scary reading, please go to http://www.qos.ch/logging/thinkAgain.jsp

So, the fact that LogFactoryImpl "specifies" that it must have a public, no-arg constructor is IMNSHO an implementation detail and irrelevant to the API.
I suspect that Commons-discovery probably go via the META-INF/services mechanism.

It is not Axis but rather how commons-discovery locates the LogFactory implementation class. There are at least two bugs here that prevent existing code that works fine with commons-logging from using pax-logging as a drop in replacement:

1. org.apache.commons.logging.LogFactory.FACTORY_DEFAULT points to a non-existent class (there is no impl.LogFactoryImpl in pax-logging)
If I run my test with the snippet from Axis that calls commons-discovery using the current pax-logging code base yields the following exception:

org.apache.commons.discovery.DiscoveryException: No implementation defined for org.apache.commons.logging.LogFactory

Which is the same one I am getting in my OSGi environment.

2. pax-logging:org.apache.commons.logging.LogFactory does not have a public no args constructor which is how commons-discovery constructs a new instance of the requested class. When I correct the FACTORY_DEFAULT string to reference to a class that exists (in this case LogFactory from pax-logging) I see this exception:

org.apache.commons.discovery.DiscoveryException: Unable to instantiate implementation class for org.apache.commons.logging.LogFactory
*****
java.lang.IllegalAccessException: Class org.apache.commons.discovery.tools.ClassUtils can not access a member of class

The solution seems to be:

1. Correct FACTORY_DEFAULT to reference a class that exists and that follows the same semantics as the one from commons-logging (public no args constructor). This class also must be in org.apache.commons.logging or org.apache.commons.logging.impl as that is what existing client bundles will have imported in a standard commons-logging situation.

Once I make the change both of these tests pass (see attached).
This test demonstrates that existing commons-discovery clients cannot use pax-logging as a drop in replacement.

I respectfully disagree with your assertion that it is a commons-discovery problem.

In the link you provided; http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/webservices/axis/branches/AXIS_1_4_FINAL/src/org/apache/axis/components/logger/LogFactory.java?view=co
which is Apache Axis, it directly uses the LogFactory class, but insist on using commons-discovery for finding the LogFactory implementation in an implementation specific manner, i.e. dictating assumptions made by commons-discovery which are not dictated by commons-logging, as commons-logging have the very simple LogFactory.getFactory() method available, which is the documented way to obtain the Factory if one needs it.

I maintain that Apache Axis should not rely on commons-discovery to find implementations of commons-logging, since commons-logging has not been made for use with commons-discovery, but something that is bolted on ad-hoc.

The simplest solution is to create a Axis Bundle that does not contain the original org.apache.components.logger.LogFactory class, but one that makes the LogFactory.getFactory() call instead. End of story.

There is no claim that Pax Logging will be a drop-in replacement for every single client-code of commons-logging et al, since there are many things not present in Pax Logging that people may call. The root cause of this is that commons-logging, log4j, JDK logging are not "API-aware", i.e. no reasonable separation between the interface and implementation, whereas Avalon Logging, SLF4J and OSGi Log Service are created with this distinction. I have tried to draw a reasonable line in the sand what constitutes API and what constitutes Implementation for especially commons-logging and log4j, and LogFactoryImpl is definitetely "implementation details". Opening the LogFactory constructor to become public is IMHO also implementation detail, since LogFactory is used as an API Singleton and no client code should create it.

For the record, I don't dispute your results from tests and analysis of why things doesn't work. I only dispute your conclusion of what the proper fix really is. I don't belong to the category of people who thinks "more mess to solve mess" is the right way forward.

Also, expect to find quite a lot of other projects/subsystems that won't work with Pax Logging and even with OSGi itself, due to such initial 'bad start' of crappy, messy, badly designed subsystems.

The discovery mechanism in both commons-logging:getLogFactory() and commons-discovery is the same (see the javadocs).

They are both going to look for a class that extends LogFactory and if they cannot find one will fall back to the one defined in FACTORY_DEFAULT which in pax-logging points to a non-existent class. This should be fixed as client code expects this field to provide a reasonable value for a default factory implementation.

pax-logging:LogFactory has broken binary compatibility and also the fundamental semantics of commons-logging:LogFactory:

1. pax-logging:LogFactory cannot be extended due to its private no-args constructor.
2. The original LogFactory is not a singleton it is an abstract class (making it impossible to change existing code to simply call getFactory())

Pax Logging is not intended to be binary compatible with the Commons Logging implementation, so subclassing of LogFactories are NOT SUPPORTED and should not be, since the surrounding environment in OSGi is too restrictive to even consider arbitrary LogFactory implementations. The API of finding the LogFactory installed IS LogFactory.getFactory() which Apache Axis should have been using in the first place. And by replacing that particular class in a fabricated Apache Axis OSGi bundle, the problem is solved.

If your argument is that FACTORY_DEFAULT should be changed, I agree, but still that won't change the private constructor limitation, since I suspect commons-discovery isn't capable of instantiating via reflection and private constructors.

There is a moral to my stubbornness, which I have hinted before; I don't agree on making possible changes just because you can. I look beyond and see what are the complications, where the slippery slope starts get out of hand. IMNSHO, a lot of sad state of software in the world is that people don't share my views of quality is only achieved by correcting the root of the problem, not hacking around it (which is what people do every day). And in this case, the correct fix is simple, non-intrusive and one doesn't even have to convince some other programmers... It is just that it is currently not a Pax issue.

[Edit: The format get buggered... Attaching solution instead.]
The solution is to change the Apache Axis code.

I disagree with the notion that Pax Logging is required to provide for the same implementation details that Commons Logging does.

Pax Logging tries to fulfill the API, not the implementation, and therefor the request in its current form bare no relevance to Pax Logging, and I maintain that the proper way for Apache Axis to do the discovery is that the fallback calls LogFactory.getFactory() which indeed is the documented API for obtaining a default factory.
Workaround would be nice in the mean time. Anyone got any tips?
Workaround is a simple class replacement in the Axis codebase. See attachment.

I know this ticket is resolved won't fix and I completely agree with the reasons behind this, but as I found this ticket via googling the error (and it's also linked to from a springsource bug report), I thought it would be good to detail the solution here - which is to fix axis' log crapness.

  1. Grab a copy of Axis 1.4 (the release AFAIK):
    • svn checkout http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/webservices/axis/branches/AXIS_1_4_FINAL AXIS_1_4_FINAL
  2. Check the README for required dependencies not included; JavaMail and javax.activation - grab these and stick them in the lib directory
  3. Apply the patch (see end of this comment)
  4. Build Axis - note you MUST use a 1.4 jdk as the Axis developers subclassed something (ResourceBundle.java AFAIR) from the rt/tools but in later jdks the overridden method is marked final
    • ant dist
  5. Crack open the distribution zip/tarball and copy out the axis and jaxrpc jars

Note: you'll still need to pax wrap it, but at least it's now usable in an OSGi environment.

The patch:

axis_1.4.patch
Index: src/org/apache/axis/components/logger/LogFactory.java
                    ===================================================================
                    --- src/org/apache/axis/components/logger/LogFactory.java (revision 1076582)
                    +++ src/org/apache/axis/components/logger/LogFactory.java (working copy)
                    @@ -19,6 +19,9 @@
                    import org.apache.commons.discovery.tools.DiscoverSingleton;
                    import org.apache.commons.logging.Log;

                    +
                    +import org.apache.commons.logging.impl.LogFactoryImpl;
                    +
                    import java.security.AccessController;
                    import java.security.PrivilegedAction;

                    @@ -38,14 +41,6 @@
                    }

                    private static final org.apache.commons.logging.LogFactory getLogFactory() {
                    - return (org.apache.commons.logging.LogFactory)
                    - AccessController.doPrivileged(
                    - new PrivilegedAction() {
                    - public Object run() {
                    - return DiscoverSingleton.find(org.apache.commons.logging.LogFactory.class,
                    - org.apache.commons.logging.LogFactory.FACTORY_PROPERTIES,
                    - org.apache.commons.logging.LogFactory.FACTORY_DEFAULT);
                    - }
                    - });
                    + return org.apache.commons.logging.LogFactory.getFactory();
                    }
                    }
                    Index: build.xml
                    ===================================================================
                    --- build.xml (revision 1076582)
                    +++ build.xml (working copy)
                    @@ -94,8 +94,8 @@
                    </depend>
                    <javac srcdir="${src.dir}" destdir="${build.dest}" nowarn="${nowarn}" debug="${debug}"
                    deprecation="${deprecation}"
                    - source="${source}"
                    - target="${target}"
                    + source="1.4"
                    + target="1.4"
                    classpathref="classpath">
                    <exclude name="**/old/**/*" />
                    <exclude name="**/bak/**"/>

hope that saves someone else some time

comments.comment:
No. Pax Logging has a hard dependency (ManagedService) on the Configuration Admin service, and there is no need to make a constipated work-around just because you decided that loading the compendium in Pax Runner is a bad idea (which I don't understand why).

IMHO, if there is a need for "ultra-thin" Pax Runner framework, then make a profile for that and stick the compendium into the profiles that are a little bit fuller.

The alternative for Pax Logging, and I think Pax Web and others, are to include the Configuration Admin package(s) within the Pax Logging Service bundle, which will just take up more space in each bundle.

I do not know about pax logging but pax web is pretty much usable without config admin. Because it does a fallback to framework/system properties.
The functionality can be implemented without the need of including system packages into the bundle. Take a look at how this is done in Pax URL.

Now the fact that I took out compendium from Pax Runner is not a problem at all. It just revealed the problem And to compensate you just need to add "compendium" to your command line.
You speak of "problem", but I fail to see that there is a "problem" at all. Having a service implement ManagedService is nothing wrong at all.
You are right, there is no "problem". My bad english . That's why the issue is an improvement not a bug.

Pax Logging Service is (and will remain) a ManagedService and therefor require Config Admin.

Pulling configuration out of system properties is just "wrong" and not in line with OSGi recommendations.

comments.comment:
I have not looked at .helpers yet, but as a general rule, a request for all methods in all classes are probably not feasible. Typically:

1. The original classes are entangled with implementation details, so it is likely that a re-implementation is needed for many/all of them.

2. It is better to extend the support one method at a time from actual use-cases.

So, could you provide a list of methods being used, and I'll take a look at that?

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-61] Update commons-logging API
item.description:
Please update the commons-logging API to 1.1.1 or higher

The LogFactory does not create a Log4JLogger when org.apache.log4j is on the system classpath.
I have to do classloading tricks to make sure the old API that is included in various PAX artefacts is not seen first.
item.summary: Update commons-logging API

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Is this 2 issues in one??

It is a known limitation that Pax Logging may or may not work for the legacy logging APIs, if the original jar file is accessible from the bundle trying to use them. You mention "on the system classpath", and I presume that you mean via the System Classloader or its parents (ExtCL and Bootstrap CL); That would also mean that you have either enabled bootclasspath delegation or exported the classes in these classloaders via the System bundle (Bundle 0), otherwise they won't create an issue.

More commonly though, is that people end up having these jars exported as bundles in their setup. Spring DM server has for instance bundlized many of these jars without properly addressing the functionality, and people often create their own wrappers or repackaging without fully understanding the underlying issues (esp in respect to collaboration across APIs).

The second issue seems to be "Update to commons logging 1.1.1"; IIRC, we are 1.1 compatible, and an point release seems to suggest "bug fix" and would most likely not affect Pax Logging. But I agree that is a huge assumption, and Ok to look at what has changed. Do you have any info on it?
Pax Logging API 1.4 does export Commons Logging 1.1.1, so what is really the issue here?
I see that this is somehow related to PAXWEB-180 Closed .

I understand that the pax-web-extender-war imports the JCL API, which pax-logging exports. I was hoping to delegate the pax-web log through pax-logging to log4j (which is on the system classpath - i.e. not provided by a bundle)

This fails with for both log4j-1.2.14 and log4j-1.2.15

Caused by: org.osgi.framework.BundleException: Error starting Bundle{org.ops4j.pax.logging.pax-logging-api:1.4.0}
                    at org.jboss.osgi.framework.bundle.OSGiBundleManager.start(OSGiBundleManager.java:843)
                    at org.jboss.osgi.framework.bundle.OSGiBundleState.start(OSGiBundleState.java:254)
                    at org.jboss.osgi.framework.bundle.AbstractBundleState.start(AbstractBundleState.java:528)
                    at org.jboss.osgi.framework.plugins.internal.AutoInstallPluginImpl.startBundles(AutoInstallPluginImpl.java:94)
                    at org.jboss.osgi.framework.bundle.OSGiBundleManager.startFramework(OSGiBundleManager.java:1137)
                    at org.jboss.osgi.framework.launch.OSGiFramework.start(OSGiFramework.java:64)
                    at org.jboss.osgi.spi.framework.OSGiBootstrap$StartupThread.run(OSGiBootstrap.java:217)
                    Caused by: java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: org.apache.log4j.Logger.setBundleContext(Lorg/osgi/framework/BundleContext;)V
                    at org.ops4j.pax.logging.internal.Activator.start(Activator.java:40)
                    at org.jboss.osgi.framework.bundle.OSGiBundleState.startInternal(OSGiBundleState.java:303)
                    at org.jboss.osgi.framework.deployers.OSGiBundleActivatorDeployer.deploy(OSGiBundleActivatorDeployer.java:49)
                    at org.jboss.osgi.framework.deployers.OSGiBundleActivatorDeployer.deploy(OSGiBundleActivatorDeployer.java:36)

I now use jcl-over-slf4j, which exposes the JCL API and delegates to log4j through SLF4J

More detail is here: https://jira.jboss.org/jira/browse/JBOSGI-161

As a net result, I need to see the pax web logs in my log4j log file, which is also used by the OSGi Framework bootstrap (i.e. before any bundle can be installed)

OK, now it starts to make more sense.

The problem is that if the external Log4J is provided into the OSGi environment, Pax Logging API can not expose the Log4J API and also consume Log4J API in the Pax Logging Service (it will potentially be wired to Pax Logging API and round we go).

So, what do you want from Pax Logging's perspective? Go back to 'exploded' Pax Logging API, so one can load up only the APIs needed/wanted?

Looking at the https://jira.jboss.org/jira/browse/JBOSGI-161, I am a little bit concerned about the approach of sticking the various Logging APIs indiscriminately into the jboss-osgi-common bundle. I think you are solving the wrong problem.

Here is what I would consider (slightly depending on whether JBoss is now an OSGi application or this is just the old-styled JBoss with OSGi capability). I am assuming the latter;

  • Use Pax Logging.
  • Strip Pax Logging API of the org.apache.log4j packages (we can create a separate artifact for this if you like).
  • Pax Logging provide a Log4J free alternate service implementation, that Imports Log4J. Then it can pick up your external one.

That will give you a much cleaner implementation and not second guessing what is going on. The only thing downstream users need to do, is to ensure that there are no logging packages visible.

WDYT?

> Pax Logging provide a Log4J free alternate service implementation, that Imports Log4J. Then it can pick up your external one.

This would be the preferred solution.

However, I consider my problem solved for now because I can successfully show that third party bundles deployed in jboss can use the JCL, SLF4J, jboss-logging or log4j APIs.

Perhaps I come back to pax-logging when I see a real use case for that.
I think end of the day there is no issue here.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-72] No implementations available for PaxAppender
item.description:
Currently it is not possible to use own appender based on log4j using existing PaxLoggingConfigurator. It is really strange because PaxLoggingConfigurator is based on log4j appenders.
There can be used only PaxAppender implementation, but none is available.

There are two solutions to solve the problem. Both are bad.

  • create own appender based on log4j appender and attach it via Fragment-Host mechanism to Pax Logging Service bundle – bad solution, because current PaxLoggingConfigurator do not support error handlers etc (I've already created PAXLOGGING-71 Closed for it)
  • write PaxAppender implementation which aggregates any log4 appender - bad, because it requires an additional log4j bundle in the application (Pax Logging exports only two log4j packages without most of log4j code, especially without appenders), what is more it is a performance killer, because PaxAppender implementation wraps some appender based on log4 appender, and PAX creates own wrapper to return log4j appender from PaxAppender...

There are two complementary solution:

  • PAXLOGGING-71 Closed
  • PaxLoggingConfigurator or its AppenderTracker should track not only PaxAppender but original log4j Appender. What is more all log4j packages should be exported.
item.summary: No implementations available for PaxAppender

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
I am not sure what this issue is really about. It talks about problems and solutions to an somewhat undefined requirement. Please clarify.

"requires an additional bundle" --> What is wrong with that? It was a goal from the start to make Pax Logging a showcase of OSGi modularity, where one would load what one needs. So, initially I wanted to achieve that each appender was its own bundle with its own configuration. That was kind of sidetracked, mostly due to time constraints. It was definitely a mistake to expose the Log4J configuration to the users, as we are now not able to change the underlying implementation to something more OSGi-friendly.

Secondly, it is not possible to "all log4j packages should be exported". I assume you mean the Pax Logging Service. That will interfere with both the Pax Logging API's need to export the Log4J API, AND it will fail to trap application code that is incompatible with Pax Logging's Log4J support. It is unwise to let application code meddle with Log4J since it may break everything and you would be no wiser of "why".

The problem is "it is not possible to use own appender based on log4j using existing PaxLoggingConfigurator."

For example I have own log4j appender implementation which extends some log4j appender implementation.
I have it already. It works perfectly in non-OSGI environment.

I'm unable to use it via PaxLoggingConfigurator, because PaxLoggingConfigurator won't see it.
PaxLoggingConfigurator sees only log4j appenders in its log4j embbeded jar.
The only way to use own appender is to provide PaxAppender as a OSGI service.

Because there is no PaxAppender implementation, i'm forced to create PaxAppender wrapper which transforms PaxLoggingEvent into log4j LoggingEvent and pass it to my own log4j appender. But I'm unable to provide own log4j appender, because PAX Logging doesn;t export all log4j code.

To do so
"it requires an additional log4j bundle in the application" - because log4j in already embedded in the PAX Logging Service.
PaxLogging API exports some log4j packages as well. So we have at least three log4j in the system. Two for PAX and one for my new appender.

"all log4j packages should be exported" - because at the moment log4j logger can be used for logging, but it is impossible to provide own appenders.

So in my opinion :
PAX Logging API should contain and export all log4j packages.
PAX Logging Service should not embed log4j jar, but should import necessary log4j packages.(from PAX Logging API bundle)
PAX Logging Service and its PaxLoggingConfigurator should be able to use not only PaxAppenders provided by OSGI service, but log4j Appenders as well. Creating AppenderBridgeImpl is not necessary.

I know that the subject is not straightforward.
The issue with PAX Logging is that its configuration is based on log4j, but it is impossible to use all log4j capabilities.

"So in my opinion" --> Not possible.
1. The Log4j packages in Pax Logging API are NOT original code and augmented to fit into the OSGi environment.

2. I want to be able to upgrade Pax Logging Service, esp the Log4j implementation (perhaps not so relevant anymore) WITHOUT stopping the entire application.

3. I strongly want to avoid DynamicImport, so it won't be possible to "just use" any class that implements Log4j Appender.

"it is impossible to use all log4j capabilities" --> Yes, and it is both by design and by necessity. Sorry.

Perhaps if you explain what you want your own Appender to do, we just create one for Pax Logging, and if there is something substantially missing in the PaxAppender approach, we add that. But since you so far is very, very vague on what you want to do, there is little I can help with.

And another thing, Yes I have contemplated many times to provide more than one Pax Logging Service implementation. LogBack, JDK Logging and even in-house one have been considered, but no real passion to do it...

My appender is org.apache.log4j.DailyRollingFileAppender with own layout and own error handler. I configure this appender in Spring DM:

 <bean id="myAppender" class="org.apache.log4j.DailyRollingFileAppender" init-method="activateOptions">
                    <property name="name" value="MyAppender"/>
                    <property name="append" value="true"/>
                    <property name="datePattern" value="'.'yyyy-MM-dd-HH"/>
                    <property name="file" value="${karaf.base}/data/log/someLog.log"/>
                    <property name="threshold">
                    <util:constant static-field="org.apache.log4j.Level.DEBUG"/>
                    </property>
                    <property name="layout">
                    <bean class="com.xxxxx.log4j.layout.SophisticatedLayout">
                    <property name="conversionPattern" value="..."/>
                    </bean>
                    </property>
                    <property name="errorHandler">
                    <bean class="com......SomeErrorHandler" init-method="activateOptions">
                    <property name="appender" ref="myAppender"/><!-- must be this appender -->
                    <property name="backupAppender" ref="someOtherAppender"/>
                    <property name="a" value="c"/>
                    <property name="b" value="d"/>
                    </bean>
                    </property>
                    </bean>

                    <bean id="myPaxAppender" class="com.......PaxLog4jAppenderWrapper">
                    <property name="log4jAppender" ref="myAppender"/>
                    </bean>

                    <osgi:service ref="myPaxAppender" interface="org.ops4j.pax.logging.spi.PaxAppender">
                    <osgi:service-properties>
                    <entry>
                    <key>
                    <util:constant static-field="org.ops4j.pax.logging.PaxLoggingService.APPENDER_NAME_PROPERTY"/>
                    </key>
                    <value>MyAppender</value>
                    </entry>
                    </osgi:service-properties>
                    </osgi:service>

and $

{karaf.base}

/etc/org.ops4j.pax.logging.cfg contains like:

log4j.logger.com.myCompany=INFO, osgi:MyAppender

This solution needs additional log4j bundle in the application, but it works.

And answer for your comments:
>1. The Log4j packages in Pax Logging API are NOT original code and augmented to fit into the OSGi environment.
What kind of changes? Could you provide some link to the docs about them, or point the classes which are changed?

>3. I strongly want to avoid DynamicImport, so it won't be possible to "just use" any class that implements Log4j Appender.
Me neither. But the appender would be provided via OSGI service as it is PaxAppender implementation, so PAX doesn't have to DynamicImport?

>"it is impossible to use all log4j capabilities" --> Yes, and it is both by design and by necessity. Sorry.
Very strange especially PAX Logging configuration is based on log4j.

>Perhaps if you explain what you want your own Appender to do, we just create one for Pax Logging,
Provide all log4j appenders as PaxAppenders and export them that other bundles can extend them.

>but no real passion to do it...
The whole OSGI is not easy as it is supposed to be.
I think with PAXLOGGING-76 Closed being fixed, such a workaround is not really needed anymore.

PAXLOGGING-76 Closed has fixed the problem partially.
To use own log4j appenders, filters or error handlers it still requires the Fragment-Host mechanism.

However it is a big step and adding a wrapper is not necessary now.
This issue is too vague to be useful. Reporter claim that the identifiable part has been addressed, and the rest seems to be outside the scope of Pax Logging.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-75] Constructor of "org.apache.log4j.Logger" is invisible
item.description:
I need a Logger Class extending "org.apache.log4j.Logger".
I difference to the SLF4J / Log4j Bundles from springsource the Pax Logging implementation hides the needed constructor.
item.summary: Constructor of "org.apache.log4j.Logger" is invisible

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Well, there are reasons for this, so a general request like this will go by without attention. You will need to provide a proper use-case, so we can discuss if it can be done in an existing manner, should be added or is undesirable/impossible to provide for.

The Logger class is not designed for inheritence, and I would like to keep it that way. I assume you are talking of the API side of the story, not the service, and since the Logger class is 'different' from the original Log4j class, it is not reasonable to expect that subclasses will work, as the subclass often knows too much intricate details of its parent class, which in this case are two different implementations (did I mention I hate inheritence?)...

Again, show me what you want to do in real terms, not an abstracted hypothetical case... and we can discuss.

I want do two things:
1. Create a logger based on log4j whos methods accept an format string and varargs: logger.error(String fmt, Object... args)
2. Create a factory that provides predefined loggers for specific topics like: Security, Journaling, ...

For an example see the sample "apache-log4j-1.2.15\examples\subclass" within the log4j zip file apache-log4j-1.2.15.zip.

If there is a better solution tell me!

As I suspected, you want to "exploit" the mess-up in Log4j, the lack of separating what is API and what is implementation. In Pax Logging, the Log4j API is abstracted to a generic form, then traverses the Bundle boundary, and gets reconstructed as a Log4j backend object. But since any API is doing the same thing, we can't pass the Log4j Logger instance across the boundary and your intent is not feasible as described by by Log4j folks (it took a while for some to get the idea of API vs implementation)....

Loggers with format string sounds like messed up separation of concerns. The app should send off events of things happening, the user configures how those are formatted. In fact, I don't see how this differs from standard Log4j configuration of formatting per appender.

Case 2; Very vague. I asked for an actual use-case, not abstract mumbo jumbo... Sorry, you need to be more specific. What does a "Security Logger" mean?
Invalid feature request.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-78] Have the bundle issuing the log event be available on all events
item.description:
Currently, the real bundle calling the logger is not really available on the log event. The native pax logging api offers a way to provide the bundle which is propageted to the PaxLoggerImpl but that one isn't used at all.

When using other apis such as jul, log4j, slf4j, the bundle used is the pax-logging-api bundle.

One possibility would be to enhance the log4j LogEvent to add the Bundle. Another one would be to use the MDC for that, but that should be done in a transparent way.
I think it should be possible to provide this information by introspecting the stack trace either when creating the logger, or when the logger is called.

We'd also have to provide a way to use this information, either by enhancing the pattern, but also by providing some way to have each bundle logging to a different file for example.

Last, with the upcoming introduction of nested frameworks (aka composite bundles), having a simple way to have each composite redirected to a different file would be nice.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-79] Read property for disabling JUL from bundle context
item.description:
The workaround for http://issues.ops4j.org/browse/PAXLOGGING-47 consists of a system property "org.ops4j.pax.logging.skipJUL" that can disable support for JUL. This property is evaluated in Activator.start().

Unfortunately we have customers that do not give us permission to set system properties in their environments. Suggested solution is reading the property from the bundle context. By this you have two options: Setting a framework property (e.g. by using launch.ini or config.ini in Equinox) and setting a system property. So the solution should be backward compatible.

I already committed my suggestion for the fix.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-88] OSGIPaxLoggingManager: m_loggers map is not thread-safe, can lead to hangs on startup
item.description:
I have observed occasional hangs of Pax Exam tests during startup of the container. These hangs happen randomly and are extremely difficult to reproduce.

I was fortunate to reproduce a hang and run "kill -QUIT" on the java process to capture a stack dump. At the time I captured the dump, the container java process had consumed approximately 30 minutes of CPU time and seemed to be in an infinite loop consuming 100% of 2 CPUs.

According to the stack dump, 2 threads in the Pax Exam container process were stuck in OSGIPaxLoggingManager.getLogger line 91, which calls HashMap.get (see stack traces below). These 2 threads were each consuming 100% of one CPU.

Looking at OSGIPaxLoggingManager.java, line 91 is accessing the m_loggers HashMap. m_loggers is not synchronized in any way.

I believe what is happen here is that concurrent accesses to the non-synchronized m_loggers HashMap are corrupting the state of the map and causing concurrent accesses to it from multiple threads to go into infinite loops within the map.

My observations and the stack traces below are based on PAX Logging version 1.4. Looking at the code for 1.5 OSGIPaxLoggingManager.java still does not synchronize m_loggers, so I think this same problem exists in 1.5.

3XMTHREADINFO "SpringOsgiExtenderThread-1" J9VMThread:0x968FB000, j9thread_t:0x0A2D683C, java/lang/Thread:0x98722C18, state:CW, prio=5
3XMTHREADINFO1 (native thread ID:0x45BE, native priority:0x5, native policy:UNKNOWN)
3XMTHREADINFO2 (native stack address range from:0x00CAC000, to:0x00CED000, size:0x41000)
3XMTHREADINFO3 Java callstack:
4XESTACKTRACE at java/util/HashMap.findNonNullKeyEntry(HashMap.java:526(Compiled Code))
4XESTACKTRACE at java/util/HashMap.getEntry(HashMap.java:510(Compiled Code))
4XESTACKTRACE at java/util/HashMap.get(HashMap.java:496(Compiled Code))
4XESTACKTRACE at org/ops4j/pax/logging/OSGIPaxLoggingManager.getLogger(OSGIPaxLoggingManager.java:91)
4XESTACKTRACE at org/apache/commons/logging/LogFactory.getInstance(LogFactory.java:269)
