item.title: [PAXLOGGING-89] JDK Logging support is not complete
item.description:
JDK Logging support is not complete.
The following log usage is not working:
import java.util.logging.Level;
import java.util.logging.Logger;
Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(MyClass.class.getName());
String parameter = "value";
logger.log(Level.FINE, "Message with parameter ''

{0}''", parameter);

1/ The log message with FINE level are never logged even if you configure PaxLogging to log message that have the DEBUG level.
This is due to the fact that with PaxLogging the Logger class is not replaced and it use its own configuration provided by the LogManager to check is the message level is ok or not.

2/ Log messages with parameters are not logged correctly. Even if you succeed to log the previous message, it will add in the log file the following message. "Message with parameter '{0}

'". No message formatting is done.
The message formatting feature is very interesting because it avoids to use the if(logger.isLoggable( Level.FINE )) pattern. The logger.log() method call will return immediately if it's not the appropriate level, without consuming performance, because parameters are not evaluated.
The old log usage form (logger.log(Level.FINE, "Message with parameter '" + parameter + "'") cost more because the message string that will be passed to the logger.log() method call is evaluated first.

Correction proposal:
1/ For the first issue, I propose to configure the JUL loggers when PaxLogging configures log4J with the following lines of code:
/**

  • Configure Java Util Logging according to the provided configuration.
  • Convert the log4j configuration to JUL config.
    *
  • It's necessary to do that, because with pax logging, JUL loggers are not replaced.
  • So we need to configure JUL loggers in order that log messages go correctly to log Handlers.
    *
  • @param log4jProps Properties coming from the 'logging.properties' config file.
    */
    private void configureJUL( final Properties log4jProps )
    {
    for (String name : log4jProps.stringPropertyNames())
    {
    String value = log4jProps.getProperty( name );
    if (name.equals( "log4j.rootLogger" )) { setJULLevel( Logger.getLogger( Logger.GLOBAL_LOGGER_NAME ), value ); }

String loggerConfigPrefix = "log4j.logger.";
if (name.startsWith( loggerConfigPrefix ))

{ String packageName = name.substring( loggerConfigPrefix.length() ); setJULLevel( Logger.getLogger( packageName ), value ); }

}
}

/**

  • Set the log level to the specified JUL logger.
  • @param logger The logger to configure
  • @param log4jLevelConfig The value contained in the property file. (For example: "ERROR, file")
    */
    private void setJULLevel( Logger logger, String log4jLevelConfig )
    Unknown macro: { String crumb[] = log4jLevelConfig.split( "," ); if (crumb.length > 0) { Level level = log4jLevelToJULLevel( crumb[0] ); logger.setLevel( level ); } }

/**

  • Convert log4j level names into JUL Level contants.
    */
    private Level log4jLevelToJULLevel( String log4jLevel )
    {
    if (log4jLevel.equals( "OFF" )) { return Level.OFF; }

    if (log4jLevel.equals( "DEBUG" ))

    { return Level.FINE; }

    if (log4jLevel.equals( "TRACE" ))

    { return Level.FINEST; }

    if (log4jLevel.equals( "INFO" ))

    { return Level.INFO; }

    if (log4jLevel.equals( "WARN" ))

    { return Level.WARNING; }

    if (log4jLevel.equals( "ERROR" ))

    { return Level.SEVERE; }

System.err.println( "WARNING: log4jLevelToJULLevel: Invalid log4jLevel '" + log4jLevel + "'" );
return Level.INFO;
}

2/ To support correctly the message parameters, a modification is required in the JdkHandler class.
In the publish() method, instead of using the record.getMessage() method, you can simply use the getFormatter().formatMessage( record ) method.
I have provided in attachment a modified version of the JdkHandler class.

Regards,
/Etienne V.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-96] Plz dont bundle the sl4fj impl w/ pax-logging-api it causes classpath problems etc
item.description: Firstly i love pax for its simplicity but its wrong imho to bundle an implementation w/ the api.jar because it is now problematic or a headache to override the impl. It also makes it difficult to mix regular java and pax tests simply because a class referring to a pax api now also pulls in the pax-logging bundled slf4j which means more headaches when there are two different incompatible slf4js. My hope would be that the two are separated. Im guessing w/ pax-logging 1.6.0 this problem is probably gone but if the two were separated then this problem should probably not repeat.
item.summary: Plz dont bundle the sl4fj impl w/ pax-logging-api it causes classpath problems etc

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Moving the slf4j implementation to pax-logging-impl is not really possible as the only interface between pax-logging-api and pax-logging-impl is the pax-logger so that the service can be made dynamic while still allowing clients to run. Not sure how to solve your problem cleanly.

Once upon a time we had the exact opposite Each support API was a separate bundle and voices was raised to cut down the number of bundles. See PAXLOGGING-8 Closed .

In general;
Don't reference Pax Logging ever.
Don't deploy other API's jars in OSGi, ever. Reference each as 'provided' in the scope of Maven.
Only deploy Pax Logging in OSGi.

That should in a vast majority of cases solve these kind of problems.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-102] Implement optional slf4j interface LocationAwareLogger
item.description:
Implementing LocationAwareLogger would allow Pax/Log4j to correctly extract location information when used in conjunction with slf4j wrappers like slf4s. Wrapping slf4j is very common in Scala code to make use of lazy eval idioms like by-name parameters. In Scala I can then write:

logger.error("I have " + numCats + " cats")

and still evaluate the string only if the error log level is set.

Providing direct support for location aware logging makes this wrapper
work and provides logging compatbility for ScalaModules (and OSGi DSL) and
it's logging wrapper Slf4s.

I have forked Pax here:

https://github.com/jadamcrain/org.ops4j.pax.logging

and am looking for some review of the changes I made. I would love for this to make the next release and particularly be incorporated into Karaf's next distribution.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-104] Slf4jLogger should implement LocationAwareLogger
item.description:
The org.slf4j.spi.LocationAwareLogger interface allows other frameworks to wrap an org.slf4j.Logger and have the location (class, method, line) reflect the caller of the wrapper rather than the wrapper itself.

The org.ops4j.pax.logging.slf4j.Slf4jLogger implementation class should implement the LocationAwareLogger interface to allow upstream wrappers to specify their own FQCN.

The implementation looks like it would be challenging because the PaxLogger interface does not have a means to pass the FQCN on a message-by-message basis. The most obvious backward-compatible approach would be to mirror SLF4J and create a LocationAwarePaxLogger subinterface of PaxLogger that adds a log() method that takes a String FQCN argument. If the Slf4jLogger gets a delegate that doesn't support FQCN, then I'm not sure what it should do. Perhaps just drop the FQCN?
item.summary: Slf4jLogger should implement LocationAwareLogger

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-115] Performance optimizations for OSGIPaxLoggingManager.getLogger()
item.description:
OSGIPaxLoggingManager.getLogger() can be a performance problem. There are two main issues: 1) it is overly synchronized, and 2) BundleHelper.getCallerBundle() calls can be expensive.

1. Right now the entire getLogger() function is synchronized. Since all log factory instances (of the same type) share the same instance of OSGIPaxLoggingManager, all "getLogger()" type of calls are essentially synchronized on the same monitor. That means that BundleHelper.getCallerBundle() is called under the monitor and that call itself can be an expensive operation.
Since there is no need to call BundleHelper.getCallerBundle() under a monitor removing the synchronized keyword on the getLogger() method will improve performance. The update to m_loggers map is already properly synchronized.

2. BundleHelper.getCallerBundle() can be an expensive operations since it uses reflection to get a bundle associated with a class. I assume the code was written to use reflection so it could work on older frameworks that do not support the FrameworkUtil.getBundle(Class) call.
I modified the code to use & compile against newer OSGi API that support the FrameworkUtil.getBundle(Class) so that when running on a newer framework there is no performance penalty (i.e. no reflection calls). And when running on an older framework things will work just like before.
item.summary: Performance optimizations for OSGIPaxLoggingManager.getLogger()

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-118] OSGI errors should not be only logged on System.out
item.description:
In class org.ops4j.pax.logging.service.internal.FrameworkHandler, all OSGi bundle and frameworks errors are logged under the same severity in the log service, by default "DEBUG".
In case a bundle fails to deploy (for instance due to unresolved dependencies), the following error is only displayed on System.out and not in the log files (see below).
It would make the troubleshooting process easier that these "ERRORS" would be logged as ERRORS, no matter what the value of the system property "org.ops4j.pax.logging.service.frameworkEventsLogLevel" (which is good at "debug" for OSGI information events).

item.description:
An MDCMatchFilter was supposed to be part of log4j 1.3. But since log4j 1.3 will never be released I think it should be added to Pax Logging itself.

This has been discussed on the OPS4J general mailing list:

http://www.mail-archive.com/general@lists.ops4j.org/msg12287.html

An MDC filter is very useful and can e g be used for selectively enabling TRACE logging based on MDC values.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-138] Pax Logging - bundle.id, name and version is not displayed in logs when the bundle use java.util.logging.Logger,
item.description:
In org.ops4j.pax.logging.service.internal.JdkHandler.publish method, there's a TODO comment like
// TODO: Can't associate a bundle with the JDK logger. So how??

the pax-logging org.ops4j.pax.logging.service.internal.JdkHandler can't associate a bundle with the JDK logger, so any bundle which use java.util.logging.Logger, can't get bundle infos in pax-logging, that's why we can't see bundle specific info(bundle name, id, version) from log if the bundle use java.util.logging.Logger, but it's OK when use other Loggers.
item.summary: Pax Logging - bundle.id, name and version is not displayed in logs when the bundle use java.util.logging.Logger,

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Attach a patch

Freeman,
Just curious, why did you choose to use the SecurityManager instead of
new Exception().getStackTrace()
to walk the caller stack?

commit fix to master

                    commit a06d511285bc933eec658a40ff73622373c386d5
                    Author: Freeman Fang <freeman.fang@gmail.com>
                    Date: Thu May 3 20:52:12 2012 +0800

                    [PAXLOGGING-138]Pax Logging - bundle.id, name and version is not displayed in logs when the bundle use java.util.logging.Logger
                    (cherry picked from commit bc6647a6cf7154f21d42e856ac08f81991200636)

to paxlogging-1.6.x branch

                    commit bc6647a6cf7154f21d42e856ac08f81991200636
                    Author: Freeman Fang <freeman.fang@gmail.com>
                    Date: Thu May 3 20:52:12 2012 +0800

                    [PAXLOGGING-138]Pax Logging - bundle.id, name and version is not displayed in logs when the bundle use java.util.logging.Logger

Hi Chris,

Both way can get the stacktrace, but from the SecurityManager we can get the stacktrace as Class[] directly, which can easily call the FrameworkUtil#getBundle(Class) to get the caller bundle.

Regards
Freeman

In master, you fixed only the code in pax-logging-service. The JdkHandler class is duplicated in pax-logging-logback, so it needs to be patched there too. Ultimately, this code duplication needs to be corrected, but in the meantime the code needs to be synchronized.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-141] JUL configuration mechanism does not in all cases follow the contract defined within the log4j configuration file for logger specific levels.
item.description:
The current delegation mechanism used by the pax logging system for JUL does not always follow the contract described within the associated log4j configuration for logger specific levels.

The specific case is when you set a level for a parent logger to a certain level and then set a child logger to a greater logging level. The child log will not be logged for messages that have a level greater than the parent and less that the child level.

For instance, if we define the following logger specific levels:

log4j.logger.com.fusesource.support.parent=INFO
log4j.logger.com.fusesource.support.parent.child=DEBUG

The parent logger would log an info log but not an fine log using a JUL call which is the expected result.
The child logger would log an info log but it will not log a fine log using a JUL call which is not the expected result.

This fine log would only be logged if the JUL root logger was set to FINE but not if it is set to INFO.

The problem is that the JdkHandler never gets the LogRecord forwarded from within JUL system. For some reason this record is purged from the messages being logged.

Was not able to determine why the JUL system purges these messages but the way that we set the JUL loggers causes those messages to not be forwarded to the log4j system that pax logging is using.

I was able to resolve this issue by not calling the setLevelToJavaLogging and setting the JUL root logger level to ALL. All log message are now forwarded to the pax logging underlying log4j system where it manages if a message is logged or not.

I've attached a patch for the 1.6.5 tag and master branch, (1.7.0) that resolves this issue.

I've also attached a simple test bundle that shows the issue with the current releases.
The test is an eclipse project that you can build and deploy within a osgi framework.
item.summary: JUL configuration mechanism does not in all cases follow the contract defined within the log4j configuration file for logger specific levels.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
See also this VERY helpful discussion of log bridging: http://www.slf4j.org/legacy.html#jul-to-slf4j

I agree that this looks like a bug, but I think your proposed solution is heavy-handed and will incur a significant performance penalty (a factor of 60 according to logback docs) because JUL logging is expensive. Instead, I recommend following the approach that Logback takes:

http://logback.qos.ch/xref/ch/qos/logback/classic/jul/LevelChangePropagator.html

This is an optional handler that explodes logback levels to JUL.

In Pax-Logging 1.7, I use logback and I've enabled JUL level bridging in the logback.xml like so:

 <contextListener class="ch.qos.logback.classic.jul.LevelChangePropagator">
                    <resetJUL>true</resetJUL>
                    </contextListener>

Chris,

Thanks for the comment and it does make sense to remove the need to be able to have to forward all of the messages to the underlying log4j system.

As for your solution, you are assuming that JUL is going to be managing all of the logging of the messages but how does your solution delegate the logging of those messages being logged from JUL to log4j or in your case logback? Do you have a Handler that you add to JUL that propagate those messages back to logback a la JdkHandler used within pax-logging?

As an aside, I decided to look into this issue a little further and it seems like the problem has nothing to do with pax-logging but in have the OSGi framework is loading the pax-logging service. In my case, it is servicemix.

I have the pax-logging service set the level for the different logger but when I try to use the same logger from another bundle. I get a different copy of the Logger instance.

I was able to determine this by displaying the JUL Logger instance identity value and they are different!
Now why does servicemix use different instances of the Logger for the same Logger name?

Alright, with a little more digging I was able to determine what was the problem. The issue is that the JUL logging system will keep a weak reference to the defined Logger instances. If those instances are not used as strong references then they will be garbage collected. When those Logger are referenced later the associated level will be set to null since the level definition is not part of the LogManager properties. Those values are set when loading from a configuration file. The solution would be to hold a reference to those defined Loggers or create a configuration file that contains the levels defined within the pax logging configuration file. I was able to fix this issue by keeping a reference to the logger specific level definitions and releasing them after every update and they'll get gc'd whenever the pax logging service is stopped. I'll attach another patch that shows how this was resolved.
Simple patch that resolve the JUL issue for v1.6.5.
This patch is for the current master branch.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-144] Ability to overwrite PAX logging default configuration
item.description:
First: I'm well aware that the ConfigurationAdmin is the preferred way of configuring PAX logging. However, I've encountered something which I cannot achieve by using ConfigurationAdmin.

In my case, I need PAX logging to log to a file as soon as its LogService becomes available. The problem is that ConfigurationAdmin might call the updated() method of PaxLoggingServiceImpl too late (indeed it often does) because it is an asynchronous call by specification. Before, PAX logging uses its default logging configuration ... which writes to Console. So my requirement is not met.

Unfortunately, it doesn't seem to be possible to change the default configuration. Okay, in PaxLoggingServiceImpl#configureDefaults(), reads some system properties but afterwards it overwrites the "log4j.rootLogger" property to use a console logger, so I don't see any chance to use a file logger instead.

I suggest that the PAX system properties are read after setting the default properties (in extractSystemProperties()), so the system properties can overwrite the default configuration.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-150] PAX Logging exports org.slf4j without importing it, leading to uses-constraint conflicts
item.description:
The pax-logging-api bundle exports package org.slf4j but does not also import it. This causes problems when other bundles (e.g the SLF4J API bundle itself) export the same interface: it leads to uses-constraint violations. For example see the following output from Felix:

Caused by: org.osgi.framework.BundleException: Uses constraint violation. Unable to resolve bundle revision org.apache.camel.camel-jetty [230.0] because it is exposed to package 'org.slf4j' from bundle revisions slf4j.api [15.0] and org.ops4j.pax.logging.pax-logging-api [153.0] via two dependency chains.

Chain 1:
                org.apache.camel.camel-jetty [230.0]
                import: (&(osgi.wiring.package=org.slf4j)(version>=1.6.0)(!(version>=2.0.0)))
                |
                export: osgi.wiring.package=org.slf4j
                slf4j.api [15.0]

                Chain 2:
                org.apache.camel.camel-jetty [230.0]
                import: (&(osgi.wiring.package=org.apache.camel.impl)(version>=2.10.0)(!(version>=2.11.0)))
                |
                export: osgi.wiring.package=org.apache.camel.impl; uses:=org.slf4j
                org.apache.camel.camel-core [208.0]
                import: (&(osgi.wiring.package=org.slf4j)(version>=1.6.0)(!(version>=2.0.0)))
                |
                export: osgi.wiring.package=org.slf4j
                org.ops4j.pax.logging.pax-logging-api [153.0]

Please add org.slf4j;version='[1.6,2.0)' as an import to this bundle. I also notice that there are a bunch of other exports with missing imports, e.g. org.apache.log4j, org.apache.juli.logging etc.

See also OSGi Core Specification section 3.5.6, "Exporting and Importing a Package".
item.summary: PAX Logging exports org.slf4j without importing it, leading to uses-constraint conflicts

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
I doubt this would be a good idea, because the code is slightly different, especially for the slf4j implementation part. In the case of pax-logging, the implementation is hardcoded, whereas in the slf4j-api bundle, the implementation is discovered using the slf4j-api bundle class loader, hence requiring the implementation to be wired as a fragment.
The APIs are compatible though, but I think importing the package would cause more problems than solving it.
In your case, a correct refresh should lead to a correct wiring (or uninstalling the slf4j-api bundle fwiw).

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-152] Support for Equinox > 3.7
item.description:
As from version 3.7, Equinox decided to register a LogService from the OSGi framework bundle (e.g. org.eclipse.osgi_3.7.2.v20120110-1415).
All Equinox bundles (e.g. declarative services) use this service (with their ExtendedLogService API).
Registering the PaxLogging allows you to capture log info from other sources (e.g. 3rd party bundles).

Problem: you end up with two independent log files, one created by Equinox (in fact by Eclipse's core runtime), one created by Pax.

Potential solution: write your own LogListeners and re-invent the merge

Probably better solution: (two parts)

1. Pax Logging does the unification.
Pax could listen for the LogEntry instances from Equinox's LogReaderService and merge these into the one Pax Logging log file.
The user could configure Eclipse's own EclipseLogWriter not to write anything (well, for now you can't afaik, but we can hope it gets added).

2. Pax Logging introduces an option to disable the registration of its own OSGi LogService API.
In Equinox, a developer does not have the option (afaik) to disable Equinox's LogService.
Adding Pax's, one ends up with two registered LogServices.
Not dramatic, but confusing anyway.
item.environment: Plain OSGi bundles running on Equinox framework.
item.summary: Support for Equinox > 3.7

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-154] RootLogger should be included in pax logging API
item.description:
We are currently integrating a third party library (fitlibrary) that references org.apache.log4j.spi.RootLogger, which causes a NoClassDefFoundError.

At first glance this class does not look to complicated. Besides org.apache.log4j.helpers.LogLog no other classes mixing from the api bundle seem to be referenced.

Is there a chance to have an implementation in the api bundle, or are there other reasons for not doing this?
item.summary: RootLogger should be included in pax logging API

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: For now you can just create a fragment bundle and provide the class yourself to see if it is working then. You can even Upload then the class so it gets integrated into the regular bundle.

The bundles are cut for a reason like this.
First question, why do you need the RootLogger? Do you need it for your own appenders?
If so you need to create your own appender and attach it to the service bundle with a fragment.
An example on how to use custom appenders can be found here
Having discovered that RootLogger is not the only class that would be needed for integrating fitlibrary an alternative solution (aka hacking fitlibrary...) seems to be more appropriate to me.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-155] Wrong JULI API version exported
item.description:
Currently pax-logging export JULI, in version 1.0, but as JULI is a tomcat component, JULI follows tomcat versioning (6.0.X or 7.0.X for example).

For example tomcat-jdbc component (the new connection pool implementation replacing dbcp) requires org.apache.juli.logging [6.0.18,7.0.0)
so pax-logging cannot be used as JULI provider because it exports JULI in 1.0 version.

Exported version should be removed for JULI
item.summary: Wrong JULI API version exported

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-157] It is not possible to disable FrameworkEvent logging
item.description:
Framework events will always sent to the backend logging (log4j) with a priority of at least DEBUG. Because of the way the OSGi Logging Service is handled, log4j cannot assess the category or the class that originated the logging. This, and the fact that no TRACE level is available in OSGi logging means it's impossible to separate framework event DEBUG logs and any thing else's.

Proposed fix: we could support a value for org.ops4j.pax.logging.service.frameworkEventsLogLevel which disables the log output alltogether. I'm attaching a possible way of doing this (it's a trivial change, I just don't know if you'd like that to be available at all)
item.summary: It is not possible to disable FrameworkEvent logging

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-160] SLF4J Marker Support with MDC attribute mapping for LOG4J 1.2
item.description:
I started using SLF4J marker, because I was expecting support for this in PAX logging already. Unfortunately I discovered that PAX logging is currently ignoring any SLF4J markers completely. Because this feature is very important to me, I discovered a way to enable marker support within PAX logging by mapping marker to an MDC attribute (slf4j.marker). It works very nice now!

I hope this patch is of interest for you and others using PAX logging already. I would very much appreciate it, if this code (or a modified version thereof) could make it to the next version, so that I don't have to use a custom patched solution, but can continue to relay on unmodified PAX logging.

Best regards
Jan

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-161] Printing full marker (chain) name for SLF4J marker
item.description:
Pax logging now supports SLF4J marker by mapping marker name to MDC attribute. However in current implementation only the marker name itself is visible in MDC attribute. But if this marker is part of a marker hierarchy these information are currently lost (not visible in MDC attribute).

I provided a patch to fix this behavior (see attachment).

My patch would transform a Marker AUTHENTICATION which is referenced to SECURITY into the following marker name:
AUTHENTICATION.SECURITY

The naming patter is similar to Domain-Names starting with the most specific and then continuing with more general marker.

If a marker has no references the result will be the same as currently. If there is a chain of markers the chain will be printed with "." separators. If there are multiple references for the same marker (in one hierarchy level) only the first (parent) marker will be resolved. I was thinking on resolving all paths and make them COMMA separated, but I decided to not do so, because this would make the name resolution to complex and providing one path should be sufficient for most cases (and is already much better than current behavior)
item.summary: Printing full marker (chain) name for SLF4J marker

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-162] Do not rely on Maven Dependency Version Ranges
item.description:
Pax Logging relies on Maven Dependency Version Ranges to point to the Logback dependencies. See https://github.com/ops4j/org.ops4j.pax.logging/blob/master/pom.xml#L146-L155.

This introduces a big handicap for users to find out which version of logback is Pax Logging ships with, as essentially it can vary every single time a release is built without even leaving a trace that the dependency was upgraded.

Of course, public sources of dependency information are unable to figure this out too: http://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.ops4j.pax.logging/pax-logging-logback/1.7.0.

The only way to find out is to look inside the JAR, and that's awfully painful!

My suggestion is to stick with fixed version numbers to aid traceability and dependency visibility for public and popular APIs like Pax Logging.
item.summary: Do not rely on Maven Dependency Version Ranges

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-165] Logback: MDC gets accidentally cleared after first logging statement from thread
item.description:
The PaxLoggerImpl of Logback follows the same behaviour as the PaxLoggerImpl for log4j, and tries to bridge two MDC implementations (PaxContext with slf4j's MDC).

This is not necessary as they are both really the same thing underneath.

In fact, setting the MDC properties before logging has no effect, but clearing the MDC properties after the logging clears the real MDC map. As a consequence, the first logging statement from the thread prints the MDC successfully, but thereon the MDC is lost. Hence, the 2nd, 3rd, etc. statements will contain no MDC any longer.
item.summary: Logback: MDC gets accidentally cleared after first logging statement from thread

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-172] Providing support for SLF4J XLogger
item.description:
While I was looking at an LOG4J example code [1] I noticed a very nice convenient method LOG.entry(...) and LOG.exit(...) to log parameter at the beginning of a method invocation at the result at the end. For me it looks like best practice to always log entry point parameter and result values at the end. Because I prefer using SLF4J I also found that SLF4J is supporting the same feature with XLogger. [2]

Unfortunately PAX-Logging does not implement this Class (including XLoggerFactory) therefore I cannot use this nice feature within my Karaf OSGi container.

I would be very happy if Pax-Logging would also provide an implementation for these two classes!

[1] https://logging.apache.org/log4j/2.x/manual/markers.html
[2] http://slf4j.org/apidocs/org/slf4j/ext/XLogger.html
item.summary: Providing support for SLF4J XLogger

just my 2 cents

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-174] Make pax logging BundleHelper configurable
item.description:
org.ops4j.pax.logging.OSGIPaxLoggingManager.getLogger() calls org.ops4j.pax.logging.internal.BundleHelper.getCallerBundle(Bundle) which analyzes the stack of classes returned from java.lang.SecurityManager.getClassContext() and returns the first bundle which is not pax-logging bundle.

What do you think about making this behaviour configurable? Maybe additional filters to skip other classes?

Real example is where some bundle defines camel-route. The bundle found during creation of org.apache.camel.component.log.LogComponent is always camel-core, not the bundle which defines the route.

regards
Grzegorz Grzybek
item.summary: Make pax logging BundleHelper configurable

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: I have an idea how to fix it - together with PAXLOGGING-252 Closed . I'm taking this issue from you

Log4j1 analyzes stack trace (from new Throwable()) bottom-up and takes first class that's not the class passed explicitly as FQCN.
pax-logging's BundleHelper traverses top-down the stacktrace from org.ops4j.pax.logging.internal.BundleHelper.SecurityManagerEx#getClassContext and finds first class that has associated bundle that's not pax-logging-api.
pax-logging's org.ops4j.pax.logging.service.internal.JdkHandler#getCallerBundle traverses top-down the stacktrace from org.ops4j.pax.logging.service.internal.JdkHandler.SecurityManagerEx#getClassContext and finds first class that doesn't have name starting with org.ops4j.pax.logging or java.util.logging.

IMO, the FCQN approach is the best one.

Fixed in recent big changes related to PAXLOGGING-252 Closed .
https://github.com/ops4j/org.ops4j.pax.logging/blob/master/pax-logging-it/src/test/java/org/ops4j/pax/logging/it/Log4J1LocationInfoIntegrationTest.java (and Log4J2LocationInfoIntegrationTest.java and LogbackLocationInfoIntegrationTest.java) shows that location is correct now through all >10 APIs.

We're successfully using it with a custom distribution based on Karaf 3.0.1, using the following steps:

  • Add pax-logging-logback to the Karaf system repository
  • Replace pax-logging-service with pax-logging-logback in etc/startup.properties
  • Put basic logback configuration in etc/logback.xml
  • Replace contents of etc/org.ops4j.pax.logging.cfg with single line: 
    org.ops4j.pax.logging.logback.config.file=${karaf.base}/etc/logback.xml
  • Note if you have an application that relies on having a static logback context then add this to etc/system.properties: 
    org.ops4j.pax.logging.StaticLogbackContext=true

    but most applications will never need to set this, it's only for a specific usecase involving legacy configuration code

    org.ops4j.pax.logging.logback.config.file=${karaf.base}/etc/logback.xml
  • etc/logback.xml – simple OSGi and logfile appenders

Hi Michael, the warning from ReconfigureOnChangeFilter is because you have scan="true" in the configuration element. This tells logback to repeatedly scan the configuration file, but this doesn't work with pax-logging because it passes a stream into JoranConfigurator and not the original file URL. This is why logback is warning automatic reconfiguration is impossible, because it doesn't have the original URL to scan.

If you remove scan="true" then the warning will go away. Also note that you don't currently define the applicationId property in your configuration, so some of your logging will probably end up in a file named "isb-applicationId_IS_UNDEFINED.log".

Finally if you want view logging using Karaf's log command then you should add the following appender:

                    <appender name="osgi" class="org.ops4j.pax.logging.logback.appender.PaxAppenderDelegate"/>

Here's a minimal logback.xml that's roughly the same as the out-of-the-box Karaf Log4j configuration:

                    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
                    <configuration>
                    <appender name="file" class="ch.qos.logback.core.rolling.RollingFileAppender">
                    <File>${karaf.data}/log/karaf.log</File>
                    <Append>true</Append>
                    <encoder>
                    <pattern>%d{ISO8601} | %-5.5p | %-16.16t | %-32.32c{1} | %X{bundle.id} - %X{bundle.name} - %X{bundle.version} | %m%n</pattern>
                    </encoder>
                    <rollingPolicy class="ch.qos.logback.core.rolling.TimeBasedRollingPolicy">
                    <fileNamePattern>${karaf.data}/log/karaf.log.%d{yyyy-MM-dd}.gz</fileNamePattern>
                    <maxHistory>10</maxHistory>
                    </rollingPolicy>
                    </appender>

                    <appender name="osgi" class="org.ops4j.pax.logging.logback.appender.PaxAppenderDelegate"/>

                    <root level="INFO">
                    <appender-ref ref="file"/>
                    <appender-ref ref="osgi"/>
                    </root>
                    </configuration>

Hope it helps

BTW, I can't see a compelling reason why pax-logging-logback has to use doConfigure(InputStream) over doConfigure(File) because it does have the file to begin with. Passing the file into the JoranConfigurator instead of a stream would likely allow use of the scan="true" reconfiguration option.

I also think the new Exception() call in configureLogbackDefaults should add some message, or maybe it should just be omitted, as at the moment it looks like an internal error in pax-logging - whereas it's actually just providing some extra context to any status warnings / errors that occur before the configuration is in place.

However, log:set does work because pax-logging-logback detects that the configuration sent over from Karaf is an attempt to configure log levels and applies them to the current context.

comments.comment:
This is very special case. I didn't expect that appender initialization would actually use logging that's being reconfigured. Checking Log4J1, Log4J2 and Logback, all internal code use some special "internal log" or "LogLog" classes that in simplest case call System.out.println().

My proposal is org.ops4j.pax.logging.useLocks option, which defaults to true, but may be changed to false for your case. It's a PID property.

I'll fix this issue by implementing this property and turning off the locking if org.ops4j.pax.logging.useLocks=false.

If you have other suggestions, please let me know.

Fixed here by making locking configurable.

If you want to skip locking, just add this to Karaf's etc/system.properties or etc/config.properties:

org.ops4j.pax.logging.useLocks = false

or this to etc/org.ops4j.pax.logging.cfg (the PID):

org.ops4j.pax.logging.useLocks = false

by default (when not specified), the locks will be used.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-192] Call clearDelegateContext() from finally block to ensure unlock of read lock
item.description:
The PaxLoggerImpl grabs a read lock in each log method (by calling setDelegateContext()) and frees the lock using clearDelegateContext(). According to the Lock javadoc, the recommended pattern is to wrap the code between the lock and unlock in a try {} block and release the lock in the finally {} section, to ensure the lock is always released, whatever happens (e.g. runtime exception).
This is properly done in the PaxLoggingServiceImpl (where the write lock is used), but not in the PaxLoggerImpl (where the read lock is used).

This issue was created to link the corresponding github pull request to it.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-199] [pax-logging-log4j2] the configuration 'org.ops4j.pax.logging.log4j2.config.file' not working in Windows
item.description:
I set the configuration the following setting in org.ops4j.pax.logging.cfg:

org.ops4j.pax.logging.log4j2.config.file = $

{karaf.etc}

/log4j2.yaml

It will cause java.net.URISyntaxException: Illegal character in opaque part at index 2 internally.

Root Cause
=========

org.ops4j.pax.logging.log4j2.internal.PaxLoggingServiceImpl#doUpdate in line: 177

URI uri = new URI(configfile.toString());
config = ConfigurationFactory.getInstance().getConfiguration("pax-logging", uri);

URI does not accept backslash file path. (ex: C:\karaf\etc\log4j2.yaml)

Possible Solution
=============

Use File instead of URI.

config = ConfigurationFactory.getInstance().getConfiguration("pax-logging", new File(configfile.toString()).toURI());

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-202] [pax-logging-log4j2] PaxLoggingServiceImpl creates LoggerContext (m_log4jContext) more than once
item.description:
I'm using the ConfigAdmin service to register log4j2 configuration in an OSGi environment. According to the current logic, PaxLoggingServiceImpl#configureDefaults method can be called multiple times where the first call is made during PaxLoggingServiceImpl constructor initialization and the other calls can come when updated method of the ManagedService is called with "configuration" object being null.

Currently each time when configureDefaults method is called, it creates a new instance of LoggerContext (m_log4jContext). This can cause issues to the loggers, if they have been intialized and added to a different m_log4jContext instance where the default log4j2 configuration was used. There can be a situation where the correct log4j2 configuration will be used only after some time (when ManagedService#updated method gets called) due to the dynamic behaviour of services. So the loggers registered before this time will use the default log4j2 configuration. These loggers can be updated with the correct config, if the same m_log4jContext instance is used all the time.

The fix here is to check and create a new LoggerContext instance only if it was not created previously.

 private void configureDefaults()
                {
                - m_log4jContext = new LoggerContext("pax-logging");
                + if (m_log4jContext == null) {
                + m_log4jContext = new LoggerContext("pax-logging");
                + }
                m_log4jContext.start(new DefaultConfiguration());
item.summary: [pax-logging-log4j2] PaxLoggingServiceImpl creates LoggerContext (m_log4jContext) more than once

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: PR for this fix : https://github.com/ops4j/org.ops4j.pax.logging/pull/17

See my comments in the PR as well.

I think that you might be a little bit short-sighted, since IIRC the idea of creating a new LoggerContext when the configuration is removed, is to get rid of the previous settings in loggers in their entirety. So, you might be fixing the wrong problem.

What "can cause issues to the loggers" are you referring to? And perhaps that is the place where the issue should be fixed.

I agree that creating new LoggerContext is to clear the previous settings of loggers, but I'm facing an issue with that. Please bare with me on the very long explanation of this issue below. There seems to be a concurrency issue when looking deeper into this.

Let's say that there are some loggers (say old") gets initiliazed before ConfigAdmin calls the updated() method. These loggers will be using a LoggerContext instance (say instance-1) which is started using the default log4j2 configuration (default log level set to "ERROR", IIRC).

Now when ConfigAdmin calls the updated method for the first time where the properties" object being null, it will create a new LoggerContext instance (say instance-2).

Any subsequent calls for updated() method from ConfigAdmin when the properties object NOT being "null" will use the same LoggerContext instance created previously (instance-2) and will be started again using the log4j2 configuration file found in properties of Configuration object using the "org.ops4j.pax.logging.log4j2.config.file key. I observed that the loggers (say new") that are initialized after this ConfigAdmin#updated call will now use the above log4j2 configuration, whereas the loggers (old") that were initialized earlier will still be using the default log4j2 configuration. I could also observe this behaviour by when these old loggers do a INFO or DEBUG level logs and they were not getting dispatched since their logger level is still at ERROR. This is what I meant as issues with some logger instances.

Initially I thought that creating new instances LoggerContext was the cause for this but when looked deeper, it was due to those loggers (old) are getting initialized using the old LoggerContext (instance-1). This was concurrently happening when these logger initializations were invoking the PaxLoggingServiceImpl#getLogger method on some threads, while configureDefaults() method was getting executed (with the updated() method call) on different thread at the same time.

Could this be an issue?

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-203] Avoid AccessControlException for property access in FallbackLogFactory
item.description:
We are using pax exam to run tests in an OSGi container. When java security is activated there is a permission required to access the "org.ops4j.pax.logging.useBufferingLogFallback" property.
This property is accessed in the FallbackLogFactory class of pax.logging.

We are using OSGi Declarative Service Components which keep the ProtectionDomain of the Service Component Runtime. This SCR loads a Class, which calls LoggerFactory.getLogger. This uses then the LoggerFactory from pax.exam instead of the one which is included in our OSGi image.

During class loading we get this exception:
java.security.AccessControlException: access denied ("java.util.PropertyPermission" "org.ops4j.pax.logging.useBufferingLogFallback" "read")

One solution would be a call to AccessController.doPrivileged(new PrivilegedAction<Void>() in the FallbackLogFactory or Slf4jLoggerFactory.getLogger to cut the ProtectionDomain stack to allow the property access.

Another idea would be to exclude pax.logging from pax.exam. But I don't know how this would work.

Do you have any other ideas?

comments.comment:
You should provide your configuration bits, especially the sifting appender config, so that we can investigate.
Also, how many different key values are used ?

One point is that the MDCSifitingAppender does not use any timer to purge old appenders. Appenders are only checked for destruction after having received a log event. The check is done at most every second, and appenders are not used if idle for 30 minutes.
So depending on your config, the number of sockets could grow.

I suggest you look at using the log4jv2 backend instead.

ayachec can you provide the configuration you've used? What's the key for SIFT configuration? May I see your etc/org.ops4j.pax.logging.cfg?

And as Guillaume Nodet mentioned, if your config uses a key that may use many many values, you may end up with many many UDP sockets.

Did you consider changing your configuration? After all, you end up in one syslog destination anyway
Please re-open this Jira with details about your configuration in order for us to investigate.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-217] Some logs are missing when the Configuration is updated via ConfigurationAdmin
item.description:
There is a small delay between, one component updating the ConfigurationAdmin with a log4j configuration and ManagedService (Log4j implementation) receiving this update due to asynchronous behavior of the OSGi ConfigurationAdmin.

Due to this behavior, there is a possibility that at start up, we could miss some log entries.
Scenario:
1. Component A update the ConfigurationAdmin with the log4j configuration.
2. org.ops4j.pax.logging.pax-logging-log4j2_1.8.5.jar get activated. But with the default configurations. ManagedService.updated() will be called in the future with a different thread.
3. In the mean time Component B get activated Which does some important initializations tasks at start up and the debug logs are very important in some cases. (these logs are missing)
4. After a moment ManagedService.updated() is called on log4j implementation. But the important logs are missing.

To address the above mentioned race condition, there should be a way to let the Log4j implementation to initialize itself with the proper configuration at the first place and update the ConfigurationAdmin if available. So that consequent call for ManagedService.updated() will have the same configuration unless another component deliberately update it.

My suggested fix is provided in https://github.com/ops4j/org.ops4j.pax.logging/pull/29
item.summary: Some logs are missing when the Configuration is updated via ConfigurationAdmin

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-223] Support skipping of JUL reset with 'org.ops4j.pax.logging.skipJULReset' property
item.description:
We configure logback with

                <contextListener class="ch.qos.logback.classic.jul.LevelChangePropagator">
                <resetJUL>true</resetJUL>
                </contextListener>

as recommended for performant logging with JUL+SLF4J.

LevelChangePropagator however only works in one direction, pushing logback configuration into JUL, it does not account for JUL configuration being changed behind its back. But this is what happens currently due to that unconditional manager.reset() call:

  • when the bundle activator creates PaxLoggingServiceImpl on line 126 and thereby boots/configures logback, log levels for logback are set and synchronized to JUL
  • when manager.reset() runs next, the JUL log levels are reset, i.e. default to INFO level, causing a disconnect between JUL and logback such that (logback) loggers that have enabled DEBUG level never receive messages because the originating JUL logger drops anything below INFO before the JdkHandler is reached

The simplest solution is to introduce a new property org.ops4j.pax.logging.skipJULReset which disables reset of the JUL, similar to how the older org.ops4j.pax.logging.skipJUL property can be used to disable JUL.
item.summary: Support skipping of JUL reset with 'org.ops4j.pax.logging.skipJULReset' property

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-224] Support for custom levels of LogService
item.description:
I'm funneling 3rd party slf4j log message through LogService which is Pax-Logging (I know I could use slf4j directly but I've my reasons not to do so)

The problem is that there are more levels in other loggers than in LogService and I can see that these levels are turned as warnings in PaxLoggingServiceImpl. This is especially annoying with TRACE level diagnostics that basically can't be turned off.

I'm scaling the slf4j levels to LogService levels with this simple formula

int logLevel = (int) (-(level - LocationAwareLogger.ERROR_INT) / 10) + 1

which not only handles the TRACE but also a notion of FATAL, that is below error level stuff.

Can the implementation be handled in linear manner so that 

                if ( level < LOG_ERROR )
                {
                logger.trace( message, exception );
                } else
                {
                switch( level )
                {
                case LOG_ERROR:
                logger.error( message, exception );
                break;
                case LOG_WARNING:
                logger.warn( message, exception );
                break;
                case LOG_INFO:
                logger.inform( message, exception );
                break;
                case LOG_DEBUG:
                logger.debug( message, exception );
                break;
                default:
                logger.trace( message, exception );
                }
                }

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-226] Make DailyZipRollingFileAppender compatible with Sift
item.description:
DailyZipRollingFileAppender currently does not take into account the individual log files being used when the Sift appender is configured. Therefore, the MaxBackupIndex is not being applied on a per bundle basis.

Also, I have noticed that current the rollover process in the DailyZipRollingFileAppender can lead to minor loss of log data if the CompressBackups option is enabled. I will create a separate issue to discuss and work on it.

Here is a sample configuration of using the DailyZipRollingFileAppender with Sift appender.

# Sift appender
                log4j.appender.sift=org.apache.log4j.sift.MDCSiftingAppender
                log4j.appender.sift.key=bundle.name
                log4j.appender.sift.default=karaf
                log4j.appender.sift.appender=org.apache.log4j.DailyZipRollingFileAppender
                log4j.appender.sift.appender.MaxBackupIndex=4
                log4j.appender.sift.appender.compressBackups=TRUE
                log4j.appender.sift.appender.DatePattern='.'yyyy-MM-dd
                log4j.appender.sift.appender.layout=org.apache.log4j.PatternLayout
                log4j.appender.sift.appender.layout.ConversionPattern=%d{ISO8601} | %-5.5p | %-16.16t | %-32.32c{1} | %m%n
                log4j.appender.sift.appender.file=${karaf.base}/logs/$\\{bundle.name\\}.log
                log4j.appender.sift.appender.append=true
item.summary: Make DailyZipRollingFileAppender compatible with Sift

item.summary: pax-logging-api and pax-logging-log4j2 have different org.apache.logging.log4j classes

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
As background; Almost all of the external APIs classes was pulled in and modified to be able to do this unification. There was one or two exceptions, but I don't recall what it was. So, assume that the main reason for copying the classes from 'back then' was to make needed modifications, and by doing so, some compromises had to be made.

That said, this missing method is not a big deal, but I am somewhat surprised that it is missing, since I would think it was always there.

The main requirement on pax-logging-api is that it does not have a dependency on any backing service or packages outside its own bundle, so that a) any loaded logging APIs aren't mistakenly used, b) if the underlying logging service is updated/refreshed the pax-logging-api bundle is NOT stopped.

HTH

Thanks NiclasH and Apologies for the delay in response.

From what i understood from the code pax-logging-api has the pax based implementation of the log4jv2 logger and pax-logging-log4j2 is responsible for registering and providing the services for logging.

I was able to replicate the issue as mentioned by the reporter (Alexey) i.e. added a dependency of pax-logging-log4j2 to the bundle which had the logging statements written. However I was able to work without any issue when i changed the dependency from pax-logging-log4j2 to pax-logging-api in my bundle and see the logging statements turn up in the logfile for "LOG.info("{}", obj);"

The NoSuchMethodError seems to occur when there is a difference compilation and runtime class which i am suspecting is the case here. Considering this when i change the dependency to pax-logging-api it seems to work fine.

Based on my investigation

1. Is there a need for making pax-logging-log4j2 bundle uber i.e. have the log4jv2 classes part of the jar? we could instead rely on the log4j2 implementation available within pax-logging-api which is already a dependency available pax-logging-log4j
2. I couldn't come across a link which showed how to use log4j2 logging with pax in bundles. I have seen few comments here and there in OPS4J groups which talks about how to configure. but nothing on how bundles should use.
3. Using the pax-logging-api instead of pax-logging-log4j2 is correct? if yes then logged in ticket is no longer a issue.
I'd create a separate issue PAXLOGGING-233 Closed (version difference); cannot use pax-logging-api (log4j2 ver 2.4.1) as dependency because at least 2.6 required (shipped with pax-logging-log4j2)
let me fix PAXLOGGING-233 Closed
PAXLOGGING-233 Closed issue no longer occurs as the manifest headers has already been corrected as part of PAXLOGGING-222 Closed

pax-logging-log4j2 embeds classes from log4j-api instead of importing them from pax-logging-api bundle. Except classcast exceptions and possible differences, pax-logging-api has shaded version of important ThreadContext class to do some OSGi magic.

I have working solution where pax-logging-log4j2 bundle embeds only classes from log4j-core and pax-logging-api has classes from log4j-api (with two shaded/changed/adjusted to OSGi classes)
Fixed here.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-237] [Log4j2] Programmatic configuration failed
item.description:
Trying to check appender from code cause [1] in console and [2] in logs

1. ERROR No log4j2 configuration file found. Using default configuration: logging only errors to the console. Set system property 'org.apache.logging.log4j.simplelog.StatusLogger.level' to TRACE to show Log4j2 internal initialization logging.

2. config.getAppenders() =

{DefaultConsole-4=DefaultConsole-4}
item.summary: [Log4j2] Programmatic configuration failed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Initial Karaf issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KARAF-5101

Observations from the peanut gallery...

1. If you want to use a Log4J version 2 backend, then you should not use the pax-logging-service, which is the Log4J version 1 backend.

2. For people looking at solving this; My guess is that Log4J2 is getting triggered "too early", for instance by the Log4J class in Activator.
For a log4j2 backend we do have the pax logging log4j2 bundle
Yes, he understood that, but both -servce and -log4j2 bundles are referenced in the pom.xml of the testcase.
pax-logging-service can be safely removed; I took pax-logging-it as input and just add pax-logging-log4j2 dep

Alexey Markevich I'm looking at your example and I see you're using convenience method:

                    org.apache.logging.log4j.core.LoggerContext#getContext(boolean)

It Avoids the type cast for:

                    (org.apache.logging.log4j.core.LoggerContext) LogManager.getContext(currentContext);

The problem is that org.apache.logging.log4j.LogManager#getContext(boolean) method is declared to return org.apache.logging.log4j.spi.LoggerContext interface and indeed, org.apache.logging.log4j.core.LoggerContext implements this SPI interfaces.

But in pax-logging-log4j2, org.ops4j.pax.logging.log4jv2.Log4jv2LoggerContext is used as org.apache.logging.log4j.spi.LoggerContext implementation and the hierarchy is:

org.apache.logging.log4j.spi.LoggerContext
                    +-- org.apache.logging.log4j.core.LoggerContext
                    | +-- org.apache.logging.log4j.core.async.AsyncLoggerContext
                    +-- org.apache.logging.log4j.simple.SimpleLoggerContext
                    +-- org.ops4j.pax.logging.log4jv2.Log4jv2LoggerContext

so, org.ops4j.pax.logging.log4jv2.Log4jv2LoggerContext is not an instance of org.apache.logging.log4j.core.LoggerContext and you're getting ClassCastException...

There's no obvious way to access org.apache.logging.log4j.core.config.Configuration as you want to do with the call to:

                    final org.apache.logging.log4j.core.config.Configuration config = LoggerContext.getContext(false).getConfiguration();

org.apache.logging.log4j.core.config.Configuration object is stored inside org.ops4j.pax.logging.log4j2.internal.PaxLoggingServiceImpl#m_log4jContext field, which is private and doesn't have getter.

Another portion of OSGi magic.

In PAX-EXAM, when org.ops4j.pax.exam.ExamSystem is created, you have several options configured using org.ops4j.pax.exam.ConfigurationManager. By default you can have exam.properties file in root of your CLASSPATH or you can point to such file using pax.exam.configuration System property.

In this file you can configure pax.exam.system property with values:

  1. org.ops4j.pax.exam.Constants#EXAM_SYSTEM_DEFAULT ("default")
  2. org.ops4j.pax.exam.Constants#EXAM_SYSTEM_JAVAEE ("javaee")
  3. any other value

In case of 3), you'll get system configured using org.ops4j.pax.exam.spi.PaxExamRuntime#defaultTestSystemOptions() with several predefined options (among others - pax-logging-api bundle!)

I changed slightly your example:

  • added exam.properties resource with pax.exam.system = default property
  • changed your org.ops4j.pax.logging.it.appender.AppenderTest#configure method to contain: 
                        workingDirectory("target/paxexam"),
                    cleanCaches(true),

                    // added implicitly by pax-exam, if pax.exam.system=test
                    // these resources are provided inside org.ops4j.pax.exam:pax-exam-link-mvn jar
                    url("link:classpath:META-INF/links/org.ops4j.base.link").startLevel(START_LEVEL_SYSTEM_BUNDLES),
                    url("link:classpath:META-INF/links/org.ops4j.pax.swissbox.core.link").startLevel(START_LEVEL_SYSTEM_BUNDLES),
                    url("link:classpath:META-INF/links/org.ops4j.pax.swissbox.extender.link").startLevel(START_LEVEL_SYSTEM_BUNDLES),
                    url("link:classpath:META-INF/links/org.ops4j.pax.swissbox.framework.link").startLevel(START_LEVEL_SYSTEM_BUNDLES),
                    url("link:classpath:META-INF/links/org.ops4j.pax.swissbox.lifecycle.link").startLevel(START_LEVEL_SYSTEM_BUNDLES),
                    url("link:classpath:META-INF/links/org.ops4j.pax.swissbox.tracker.link").startLevel(START_LEVEL_SYSTEM_BUNDLES),
                    url("link:classpath:META-INF/links/org.ops4j.pax.exam.link").startLevel(START_LEVEL_SYSTEM_BUNDLES),
                    url("link:classpath:META-INF/links/org.ops4j.pax.exam.inject.link").startLevel(START_LEVEL_SYSTEM_BUNDLES),
                    url("link:classpath:META-INF/links/org.ops4j.pax.extender.service.link").startLevel(START_LEVEL_SYSTEM_BUNDLES),

                    // configadmin should start before org.ops4j.pax.logging.pax-logging-log4j2
                    linkBundle("org.apache.felix.configadmin").startLevel(START_LEVEL_SYSTEM_BUNDLES),

                    // added implicitly by pax-exam, if pax.exam.system=test
                    // - url("link:classpath:META-INF/links/org.ops4j.pax.logging.api.link").startLevel( START_LEVEL_SYSTEM_BUNDLES),
                    // - url("link:classpath:META-INF/links/org.osgi.compendium.link").startLevel( START_LEVEL_SYSTEM_BUNDLES),
                    // but we will use versions aligned to pax-web:
                    url("link:classpath:META-INF/links/org.apache.geronimo.specs.atinject.link").startLevel(START_LEVEL_SYSTEM_BUNDLES),

                    CoreOptions.junitBundles(),
                    mavenBundle().artifactId("pax-logging-api").groupId("org.ops4j.pax.logging").version("1.10.1-SNAPSHOT"),
                    mavenBundle().artifactId("pax-logging-log4j2").groupId("org.ops4j.pax.logging").version("1.10.1-SNAPSHOT")
  • these url("link:classpath:META-INF/links/... will be resolved using resources embedded inside pax-exam-link-mvn bundle
  • this linkBundle("org.apache.felix.configadmin") comes from explicit resource inside src/test/resources/org.apache.felix.configadmin.link, which contains (configadmin is needed for pax-logging-log4j2): 
    mvn:org.apache.felix/org.apache.felix.configadmin/1.8.14
  • in order to be able to use property placeholders, you can't have just log4j2.property.pattern and use {{log4j2.appender.console.layout.pattern = $ {log4j2.pattern}

    }}, because prefix log4j2. is stripped and org.apache.logging.log4j.core.config.properties.PropertiesConfigurationBuilder#build detects generic properties to be prefixed by property., so you have to have:

    # Common pattern layout for appenders
                    log4j2.property.pattern = %d{ISO8601} | %-5p | %-16t | %-32c{1} | %X{bundle.id} - %X{bundle.name} - %X{bundle.version} | %m%n
                    
                    log4j2.appender.console.layout.pattern = ${pattern}

This way you'll have working example

Ah - and shorter explanation - if you use default pax-exam configuration, which explicitly adds pax-logging-api bundle, with mavenBundle().artifactId("pax-logging-api").groupId("org.ops4j.pax.logging").version("1.10.0"), you'll have two pax-logging-api bundles and your test class will configure the latter one, while loggers will come/be configured using the first one - that's why you saw failed test.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-238] JDK loglevel can not be configured with log4j2 properties
item.description:
When using log4j2 with paxlogging, the log level is not adapted to the log levels of the log4j2 properties in the config file.

This is due to PaxLoggingServiceImpl still using old log4j properties to retrieve and set the JULLevel of the JULLoggers and not taking into account the log levels of the log4j2 properties:

                if (name.equals( "log4j.rootLogger" )) {
                setJULLevel( java.util.logging.Logger.getLogger(""), value );
                // "global" comes from java.util.logging.Logger.GLOBAL_LOGGER_NAME, but that constant wasn't added until Java 1.6
                 setJULLevel( java.util.logging.Logger.getLogger("global"), value );
                }

                if (name.startsWith("log4j.logger.")) {
                String packageName = name.substring( "log4j.logger.".length() );
                java.util.logging.Logger logger = java.util.logging.Logger.getLogger(packageName);
                setJULLevel(logger, value);

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-239] ClassLoader leak when pax-logging-log4j2 bundle is refreshed
item.description:
When pax-logging-log4j2 bundle is refreshed (new wiring is created for it), the related classloader is still referenced using strong reference.

Here's the graph:

this - value: org.apache.felix.framework.BundleWiringImpl #8
                <- m_wiring - class: org.apache.felix.framework.BundleWiringImpl$BundleClassLoader, value: org.apache.felix.framework.BundleWiringImpl #8
                <- <classLoader> - class: org.apache.logging.log4j.core.impl.MutableLogEvent, value: org.apache.felix.framework.BundleWiringImpl$BundleClassLoader #5
                <- <class> - class: org.apache.logging.log4j.core.impl.MutableLogEvent, value: org.apache.logging.log4j.core.impl.MutableLogEvent class MutableLogEvent
                <- value - class: java.lang.ThreadLocal$ThreadLocalMap$Entry, value: org.apache.logging.log4j.core.impl.MutableLogEvent #1
                <- [149] - class: java.lang.ThreadLocal$ThreadLocalMap$Entry[], value: java.lang.ThreadLocal$ThreadLocalMap$Entry #124
                <- table - class: java.lang.ThreadLocal$ThreadLocalMap, value: java.lang.ThreadLocal$ThreadLocalMap$Entry[] #40
                <- threadLocals (thread object) - class: java.lang.Thread, value: java.lang.ThreadLocal$ThreadLocalMap #15

The problem is that default, org.apache.logging.log4j.core.impl.ReusableLogEventFactory keeps references to org.apache.logging.log4j.core.impl.MutableLogEvent instances in thread local org.apache.logging.log4j.core.impl.ReusableLogEventFactory#mutableLogEventThreadLocal.

When Karaf 4.1.1 starts it installs pax-logging-log4j2 bundle from etc/startup.properties, but then, when shell feature is installed, pax-logging-log4j2 bundle is rewired because optional import to org.fusesource.jansi package is now satisfied (from mvn:org.fusesource.jansi/jansi/1.16 bundle in shell feature).

I found that after the refresh, two instances of org.apache.felix.framework.BundleWiringImpl exist for pax-logging-log4j2 bundle.

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-242] Log level values are not case insensitive for JUL
item.description:
Log4J treats the log level values as case insensitive. So it is possible to give it a value 'ERROR' as well as 'error'.

Pax Logging behaves in the same way when the underlying logger is Log4J, but not when the underlying logger is the Java Util Logging. This means that when such a log level is defined as 'error', it will fall back to INFO instead, which is very strange behavior.

See here that Log4J is case insensitive:
https://github.com/apache/logging-log4j2/blob/log4j-2.9.0/log4j-api/src/main/java/org/apache/logging/log4j/Level.java#L287

This bug is linked to fixes in https://ops4j1.jira.com/browse/PAXLOGGING-238

comments.comment: Niels Berghen, pax-logging doesn't read JUL properties configuration... What's your setup and where do you want to configure JUL for pax-logging?

I used this function when doing changes related to PAXLOGGING-252 Closed . It should help:

                    /**
                    * Converts pax-logging level name (anything that pax-logging supports, case-insensitive) to {@link Level}
                    * from {@code java.util.logging}. If nothing can be parsed, {@link Level#INFO} is returned.
                    * @param levelName
                    * @return
                    */
                    public static Level toJULLevel(String levelName) {
                    if (levelName == null || levelName.equalsIgnoreCase("OFF")) {
                    return Level.OFF;
                    } else if (levelName.equalsIgnoreCase("FATAL") || levelName.equalsIgnoreCase("SEVERE") || levelName.equalsIgnoreCase("ERROR")) {
                    return Level.SEVERE;
                    } else if (levelName.equalsIgnoreCase("WARN") || levelName.equalsIgnoreCase("WARNING")) {
                    return Level.WARNING;
                    } else if (levelName.equalsIgnoreCase("INFO") || levelName.equalsIgnoreCase("CONFIG") || levelName.equalsIgnoreCase("CONF")) {
                    return Level.INFO;
                    } else if (levelName.equalsIgnoreCase("DEBUG") || levelName.equalsIgnoreCase("FINE")) {
                    return Level.FINE;
                    } else if (levelName.equalsIgnoreCase("TRACE") || levelName.equalsIgnoreCase("FINER")) {
                    return Level.FINER;
                    } else if (levelName.equalsIgnoreCase("FINEST")) {
                    return Level.FINEST;
                    } else if (levelName.equalsIgnoreCase("ALL")) {
                    return Level.ALL;
                    }
                    return Level.INFO;
                    }

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-243] Incorrect bundle names in the logs in case of the logs come from embeded lib
item.description:
Given a common lib which is used for multiple bundles for logging purpose, (see https://github.com/xldai/test/tree/master/test-log4j2-common), there are 2 bundles which generate logging using this common lib (see https://github.com/xldai/test/tree/master/test-log4j2-bundle1 and https://github.com/xldai/test/tree/master/test-log4j2-bundle2), After build these 2 bundles and deployed them into karaf OSGi container, you can find the bundle.id/bundle.name in the logs is always come from the bundle which first got deployed.

                2017-10-23T19:10:54,936 | INFO | qtp2133857677-113 | beans.CommonLoggingBean 12 | 298 - test-log4j2-bundle1 - 1.0.0 | log from Bundle1
                2017-10-23T19:10:56,332 | INFO | qtp2133857677-109 | beans.CommonLoggingBean 12 | 298 - test-log4j2-bundle1 - 1.0.0 | log from Bundle2

After some debugging, I found that an ConcurrentMap<String, PaxLoggerImpl> is used to store/get the Logger for specific class in the PaxLoggingServiceImpl of the the pax-logging-log4j2-1.10.1 bundle, it only store the PaxLoggerImpl which first deployed for the same key.

I made a patched pax-logging-log4j2-1.10.1 bundle with these changes, and then the correct bundle.id/bundle.name can be generated from the logs.

                if (logger == null) {
                logger = new PaxLoggerImpl( bundle, m_log4jContext.getLogger(name), fqcn, this );
                m_loggers.putIfAbsent( name, logger );
                + } else {
                + String bundleName = (String)logger.getPaxContext().get("bundle.name");
                + if (null != bundle && !bundle.getSymbolicName().equals(bundleName)) {
                + logger = new PaxLoggerImpl( bundle, m_log4jContext.getLogger(name), fqcn, this );
                + m_loggers.put( name, logger );
                + }
                + }
item.summary: Incorrect bundle names in the logs in case of the logs come from embeded lib

comments.comment: The patch is not correct. Rather org.ops4j.pax.logging.log4j2.internal.PaxLoggingServiceImpl#m_loggers should be indexed using logger name and bundle symbolic name combined. This patch simply overrides previous logger.
What's even worse is that if you completely uninstall first bundle that grabbed given logger, it is still used (until you refresh pax-logging bundle)
Looks like only pax-logging-log4j2 does own caching. pax-logging-service and pax-logging-logback rely on impl caching instead.

I removed this caching entirely and provided an mdcSiftingAppender integration test in https://github.com/ops4j/org.ops4j.pax.logging/blob/master/pax-logging-it/src/test/java/org/ops4j/pax/logging/it/Log4J2BuiltinAppendersIntegrationTest.java that tests if same category of logger obtained from different bundles actually gives you two different loggers.

item.summary: pax-logging-api/Slf4jMDCAdapter uses stale MDC after refreshing service bundle

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
The reproducer is:

A single bundle with single activator with start() method:

                    @Override
                    public void start(BundleContext context) throws Exception {
                    File karafData = new File(System.getProperty("karaf.data"));
                    executor = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(1);
                    executor.submit(() -> {
                    try {
                    while (true) {
                    Thread.sleep(500);
                    File marker = new File(karafData, "marker");
                    if (marker.isFile()) {
                    try {
                    byte[] bytes = Files.readAllBytes(Paths.get(marker.toURI()));
                    MDC.put("my.key", "key42");
                    LOG.info("GG: {}", new String(bytes, "UTF-8"));
                    MDC.clear();
                    marker.delete();
                    } catch (IOException e) {
                    e.printStackTrace();
                    }
                    }
                    }
                    } catch (InterruptedException e) {
                    Thread.currentThread().interrupt();
                    System.out.println("Stopped logging thread");
                    }
                    });
                    }

Changed logging configuration (added MDC key):

log4j.appender.out.layout.ConversionPattern=%d{ISO8601} | %-5.5p | {%t} [%C] (%F:%L) key=<%X{my.key}> | %m%n

the activator checks for $KARAF_HOME/data/marker file and when found, logs its content and then removes it:

$ echo -n test > data/marker

And in logs we can see:

2018-01-09 12:19:33,226 | INFO | {pool-29-thread-1} [grgr.test.Activator] (Activator.java:52) key=<key42> | GG: test

After refreshing pax-logging-service:

karaf:karaf@root> refresh --force org.ops4j.pax.logging.pax-logging-service

We no longer see the key:

2018-01-09 12:20:45,254 | INFO | {pool-29-thread-1} [grgr.test.Activator] (Activator.java:52) key=<> | GG: test
Looks like the most obvious solution is to reinitialize org.ops4j.pax.logging.slf4j.Slf4jMDCAdapter#m_context.
PR: https://github.com/ops4j/org.ops4j.pax.logging/pull/36
Handled with PAXLOGGING-252 Closed .

org.apache.log4j.MDC#getPaxContext, org.ops4j.pax.logging.log4jv2.Log4jv2ThreadContextMap#getContext() and org.ops4j.pax.logging.slf4j.Slf4jMDCAdapter#getContext always delegate to underlying PaxLoggingService (if there's one).

item.title: [PAXLOGGING-263] Log4j should be configurable using defaults file
item.description:
Log4j should be configurable using defaults file

We'd like to configure Log4j using an additional, optional defaults file.
This allows us to split the configuration into "user" and "system" settings.
User settings will take precedence over system settings.

This solves the following problem:
Currently, users of our software may alter the logger configuration directly;
updating the system then becomes tedious, since we can't merge the updated system configuration into the modified configuration easily.

Details:
We'd like the defaults to be stored in a properties file.
It should look like the existing Log4j configuration in its properties syntax.
So if existing, this file should be taken into account.
The name of the file should be kept in the bundle configuration under the key "org.ops4j.pax.logging.log4j2.defaults.file".

Will provide a PR...
item.summary: Log4j should be configurable using defaults file

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
The PR is always welcomed.

However, at first glance it looks like its not trivial change, as the source of configuration is Configuration Admin service and org.ops4j.pax.logging PID.

Our PR is an addition to the Log4j initialization made by pax logging.

It works like this:
Pax logging receives configuration from the Configuration Admin and then decides how to configure Log4j with it.
Currently, there are two possible ways: either pass properties directly to Log4j or let Log4j read an xml file.
We've added a bit more logic to the "pass properties directly" case, where we merge in the contents of the default file if it's available.

I've moved this org.ops4j.pax.logging.log4j2.defaults.file literal as constant inside org.ops4j.pax.logging.PaxLoggingConstants#PID_CFG_LOG4J2_DEFAULTS_FILE without changing the behavior.

Now that I've finally found the time to check it, I appreciate the simplicity and usefulness of this option .
